description: Add vectors end-to-end, component-wise, and by the parallelogram rule. Understand that the magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes.

subject: Math
description: Given two vectors in magnitude and direction form, determine the magnitude and direction of their sum.

subject: Math
description: Understand vector subtraction v - w as v + (-w), where -w is the additive inverse of w, with the same magnitude as w and pointing in the opposite direction. Represent vector subtraction graphically by connecting the tips in the appropriate order, and perform vector subtraction component-wise.

subject: Math
description: (+) Multiply a vector by a scalar.

subject: Math
description: Represent scalar multiplication graphically by scaling vectors and possibly reversing their direction; perform scalar multiplication component-wise, e.g., as c(v<sub>x</sub>, v<sub>y</sub>) = (cv<sub>x</sub>, cv<sub>y</sub>).

subject: Math
description: Compute the magnitude of a scalar multiple cv using ||cv|| = |c|v. Compute the direction of cv knowing that when |c|v ? 0, the direction of cv is either along v (for c > 0) or against v (for c < 0).

subject: Math
description: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.

subject: Math
description: (+) Use matrices to represent and manipulate data, e.g., to represent payoffs or incidence relationships in a network.

subject: Math
description: (+) Multiply matrices by scalars to produce new matrices, e.g., as when all of the payoffs in a game are doubled.

subject: Math
description: (+) Add, subtract, and multiply matrices of appropriate dimensions.

subject: Math
description: (+) Understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties.

subject: Math
description: (+) Understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse.

subject: Math
description: (+) Multiply a vector (regarded as a matrix with one column) by a matrix of suitable dimensions to produce another vector. Work with matrices as transformations of vectors.

subject: Math
description: (+) Work with 2 × 2 matrices as transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the determinant in terms of area.

subject: Math
description: Interpret the structure of expressions

subject: Math
description: Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context <sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors, and coefficients.

subject: Math
description: Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity.

subject: Math
description: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it.

subject: Math
description: Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

subject: Math
description: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.

subject: Math
description: Complete the square in a quadratic expression to reveal the maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.

subject: Math
description: Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions.

subject: Math
description: Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series (when the common ratio is not 1), and use the formula to solve problems.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Perform arithmetic operations on polynomials

subject: Math
description: Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

subject: Math
description: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials

subject: Math
description: Know and apply the Remainder Theorem: For a polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by x - a is p(a), so p(a) = 0 if and only if (x - a) is a factor of p(x).

subject: Math
description: Identify zeros of polynomials when suitable factorizations are available, and use the zeros to construct a rough graph of the function defined by the polynomial.

subject: Math
description: Use polynomial identities to solve problems

subject: Math
description: Prove polynomial identities and use them to describe numerical relationships.

subject: Math
description: (+) Know and apply the Binomial Theorem for the expansion of (x + y)<sup>n</sup> in powers of x and y for a positive integer n, where x and y are any numbers, with coefficients determined for example by Pascal's Triangle.

subject: Math
description: Rewrite rational expressions

subject: Math
description: Rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms; write <sup>a(x </sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub> in the form q(x) + <sup>r(x)</sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub>, where a(x), b(x), q(x), and r(x) are polynomials with the degree of r(x) less than the degree of b(x), using inspection, long division, or, for the more complicated examples, a computer algebra system.

subject: Math
description: (+) Understand that rational expressions form a system analogous to the rational numbers, closed under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by a nonzero rational expression; add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.

subject: Math
description: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships

subject: Math
description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.

subject: Math
description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

subject: Math
description: Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable or nonviable options in a modeling context.

subject: Math
description: Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations.

subject: Math
description: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning

subject: Math
description: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify a solution method.

subject: Math
description: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.

subject: Math
description: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

subject: Math
description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

subject: Math
description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

subject: Math
description: Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in x into an equation of the form (x - p)² = q that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic formula from this form.

subject: Math
description: Solve quadratic equations by inspection (e.g., for x² = 49), taking square roots, completing the square, the quadratic formula and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation. Recognize when the quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as a ± bi for real numbers a and b.

subject: Math
description: Solve systems of equations

subject: Math
description: Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.

subject: Math
description: Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.

subject: Math
description: Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically.

subject: Math
description: (+) Represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable.

subject: Math
description: (+) Find the inverse of a matrix if it exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations (using technology for matrices of dimension 3 × 3 or greater).

subject: Math
description: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically

subject: Math
description: Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).

subject: Math
description: Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using technology to graph the functions, make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are linear, polynomial, rational, absolute value, exponential, and logarithmic functions.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

subject: Math
description: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation

subject: Math
description: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).

subject: Math
description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context.

subject: Math
description: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers.

subject: Math
description: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context

subject: Math
description: For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Analyze functions using different representations

subject: Math
description: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Graph linear and quadratic functions and show intercepts, maxima, and minima.

subject: Math
description: Graph square root, cube root, and piecewise-defined functions, including step functions and absolute value functions.

subject: Math
description: Graph polynomial functions, identifying zeros when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.

subject: Math
description: (+) Graph rational functions, identifying zeros and asymptotes when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.

subject: Math
description: Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts and end behavior, and trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude.

subject: Math
description: Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.

subject: Math
description: Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a context.

subject: Math
description: Use the properties of exponents to interpret expressions for exponential functions.

subject: Math
description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).

subject: Math
description: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

subject: Math
description: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities <sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or steps for calculation from a context.

subject: Math
description: Combine standard function types using arithmetic operations.

subject: Math
description: (+) Compose functions.

subject: Math
description: Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate between the two forms.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Build new functions from existing functions

subject: Math
description: Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, k f(x), f(kx), and f(x + k) for specific values of k (both positive and negative); find the value of k given the graphs. Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.

subject: Math
description: Find inverse functions.

subject: Math
description: Solve an equation of the form f(x) = c for a simple function f that has an inverse and write an expression for the inverse.

subject: Math
description: (+) Verify by composition that one function is the inverse of another.

subject: Math
description: (+) Read values of an inverse function from a graph or a table, given that the function has an inverse.

subject: Math
description: (+) Produce an invertible function from a non-invertible function by restricting the domain.

subject: Math
description: (+) Understand the inverse relationship between exponents and logarithms and use this relationship to solve problems involving logarithms and exponents.

subject: Math
description: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

subject: Math
description: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.

subject: Math
description: Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals, and that exponential functions grow by equal factors over equal intervals.

subject: Math
description: Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit interval relative to another.

subject: Math
description: Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per unit interval relative to another.

subject: Math
description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a table).

subject: Math
description: Observe using graphs and tables that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.

subject: Math
description: For exponential models, express as a logarithm the solution to ab<sup>ct</sup> = d where a, c, and d are numbers and the base b is 2, 10, or e; evaluate the logarithm using technology.

subject: Math
description: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model

subject: Math
description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function in terms of a context.

subject: Math
description: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

subject: Math
description: Understand radian measure of an angle as the length of the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle.

subject: Math
description: Explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit circle.

subject: Math
description: (+) Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent for π/3, π/4 and π/6, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, and tangent for π-x, π+x, and 2π-x in terms of their values for x, where x is any real number.

subject: Math
description: (+) Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric functions.

subject: Math
description: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions

subject: Math
description: Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: (+) Understand that restricting a trigonometric function to a domain on which it is always increasing or always decreasing allows its inverse to be constructed.

subject: Math
description: (+) Use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Prove and apply trigonometric identities

subject: Math
description: Prove the Pythagorean identity sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1 and use it to find sin(θ), cos(θ), or tan(θ) given sin(θ), cos(θ), or tan(θ) and the quadrant of the angle.

subject: Math
description: (+) Prove the addition and subtraction formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve problems.

subject: Math
description: Experiment with transformations in the plane

subject: Math
description: Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.

subject: Math
description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

subject: Math
description: Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.

subject: Math
description: Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.

subject: Math
description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using, e.g., graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

subject: Math
description: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions

subject: Math
description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.

subject: Math
description: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.

subject: Math
description: Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions.

subject: Math
description: Prove geometric theorems

subject: Math
description: Prove theorems about lines and angles.

subject: Math
description: Prove theorems about triangles.

subject: Math
description: Prove theorems about parallelograms.

subject: Math
description: Make geometric constructions

subject: Math
description: Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.

subject: Math
description: Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.

subject: Math
description: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

subject: Math
description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

subject: Math
description: A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged.

subject: Math
description: The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.

subject: Math
description: Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides.

subject: Math
description: Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.

subject: Math
description: Prove theorems involving similarity

subject: Math
description: Prove theorems about triangles.

subject: Math
description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

subject: Math
description: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

subject: Math
description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

subject: Math
description: Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.

subject: Math
description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Apply trigonometry to general triangles

subject: Math
description: (+) Derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.

subject: Math
description: (+) Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.

subject: Math
description: (+) Understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces).

subject: Math
description: Understand and apply theorems about circles

subject: Math
description: Prove that all circles are similar.

subject: Math
description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords.

subject: Math
description: Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.

subject: Math
description: (+) Construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle.

subject: Math
description: Find arc lengths and areas of sectors of circles

subject: Math
description: Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.

subject: Math
description: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

subject: Math
description: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.

subject: Math
description: Derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix.

subject: Math
description: (+) Derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant.

subject: Math
description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

subject: Math
description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.

subject: Math
description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

subject: Math
description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

subject: Math
description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles, e.g., using the distance formula.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems

subject: Math
description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone.

subject: Math
description: (+) Give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures.

subject: Math
description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects

subject: Math
description: Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.

subject: Math
description: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations

subject: Math
description: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot).<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios).<sup>★</sup>

subject: Math
description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable

subject: Math
description: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).

subject: Math
description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

subject: Math
description: Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).

subject: Math
description: Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate. Use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve.

subject: Math
description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables

subject: Math
description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

subject: Math
description: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.

subject: Math
description: Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve problems in the context of the data.

subject: Math
description: Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing residuals.

subject: Math
description: Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.

subject: Math
description: Interpret linear models

subject: Math
description: Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.

subject: Math
description: Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.

subject: Math
description: Distinguish between correlation and causation.

subject: Math
description: Understand and evaluate random processes underlying statistical experiments

subject: Math
description: Understand statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters based on a random sample from that population.

subject: Math
description: Decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a given data-generating process, e.g., using simulation.

subject: Math
description: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies

subject: Math
description: Recognize the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how randomization relates to each.

subject: Math
description: Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of error through the use of simulation models for random sampling.

subject: Math
description: Use data from a randomized experiment to compare two treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters are significant.

subject: Math
description: Evaluate reports based on data.

subject: Math
description: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data

subject: Math
description: Describe events as subsets of a sample space (the set of outcomes) using characteristics (or categories) of the outcomes, or as unions, intersections, or complements of other events ("or," "and," "not").

subject: Math
description: Understand that two events A and B are independent if the probability of A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, and use this characterization to determine if they are independent.

subject: Math
description: Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B), and interpret independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B.

subject: Math
description: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities.

subject: Math
description: Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday language and everyday situations.

subject: Math
description: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model

subject: Math
description: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B's outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

subject: Math
description: Apply the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

subject: Math
description: (+) Apply the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

subject: Math
description: (+) Use permutations and combinations to compute probabilities of compound events and solve problems.

subject: Math
description: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems

subject: Math
description: (+) Define a random variable for a quantity of interest by assigning a numerical value to each event in a sample space; graph the corresponding probability distribution using the same graphical displays as for data distributions.

subject: Math
description: (+) Calculate the expected value of a random variable; interpret it as the mean of the probability distribution.

subject: Math
description: (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which theoretical probabilities can be calculated; find the expected value.

subject: Math
description: (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which probabilities are assigned empirically; find the expected value.

subject: Math
description: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions

subject: Math
description: (+) Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.

subject: Math
description: Find the expected payoff for a game of chance.

subject: Math
description: Evaluate and compare strategies on the basis of expected values.

subject: Math
description: (+) Use probabilities to make fair decisions (e.g., drawing by lots, using a random number generator).

subject: Math
description: (+) Analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts (e.g., product testing, medical testing, pulling a hockey goalie at the end of a game).

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate an understanding of rules by following most classroom routines.

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate responsibility by initiating simple classroom tasks and jobs.

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate appropriate behavior when collaborating with others.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how rules and laws created by community, state, and national governments protect the rights of people, help resolve conflicts, and promote the common good.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how fundamental rights guaranteed by the United States Constitution and the Bill of Rights (i.e., freedom of expression, freedom of religion, the right to vote, and the right to due process) contribute to the continuation and improvement of American democracy.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine how "fairness," "equality," and the "common good" have influenced new laws and policies over time at the local and national levels of United States government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the United States government is organized and how the United States Constitution defines and checks the power of government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish the roles and responsibilities of the three branches of the national government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how national and state governments share power in the federal system of government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the United States functions as a representative democracy, and describe the roles of elected representatives and how they interact with citizens at local, state, and national levels.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast how government functions at the community, county, state, and national levels, the services provided, and the impact of policy decisions made at each level.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast responses of individuals and groups, past and present, to violations of fundamental rights (e.g., fairness, civil rights, human rights).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the actions of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and other civil rights leaders served as catalysts for social change and inspired social activism in subsequent generations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the fundamental rights of the individual and the common good of the country depend upon all citizens exercising their civic responsibilities at the community, state, national, and global levels.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the process of creating change at the local, state, or national level.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the process by which immigrants become United States citizens.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the world is divided into many nations that have their own governments, languages, customs, and laws.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how and why it is important that people from diverse cultures collaborate to find solutions to community, state, national, and global challenges.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explore how national and international leaders, businesses, and global organizations promote human rights and provide aid to individuals and nations in need.

subject: Social Studies
description: Develop an awareness of the physical features of the neighborhood/community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify, discuss, and role-play the duties of a range of community workers.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast information that can be found on different types of maps and determine how the information may be useful.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use physical and political maps to explain how the location and spatial relationship of places in New Jersey, the United States, and other areas, worldwide, have contributed to cultural diffusion and economic interdependence.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how and when it is important to use digital geographic tools, political maps, and globes to measure distances and to determine time zones and locations using latitude and longitude.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how landforms, climate and weather, and availability of resources have impacted where and how people live and work in different regions of New Jersey and the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how human interaction impacts the environment in New Jersey and the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast characteristics of regions in the United States based on culture, economics, and physical environment to understand the concept of regionalism.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why some locations in New Jersey and the United States are more suited for settlement than others.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare ways people choose to use and distribute natural resources.

subject: Social Studies
description: Relate advances in science and technology to environmental concerns, and to actions taken to address them.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify major cities in New Jersey, as well as in the United States, and the world, and explain how geographic and demographic tools (e.g., maps, globes, data visualizations) can be used to understand cultural differences.

subject: Social Studies
description: Apply opportunity cost (i.e., choices and tradeoffs) to evaluate individuals' decisions, including ones made in their communities.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between needs and wants and explain how scarcity and choice influence decisions made by individuals, communities, and nations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why incentives vary between and among producers and consumers.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how supply and demand influence price and output of products.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the role of specialization in the production and exchange of goods and services.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the role and relationship among households, businesses, laborers, and governments within the economic system.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the availability of private and public goods and services is influenced by the global market and government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Illustrate how production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services are interrelated and are affected by the global market and events in the world community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast how the availability of resources affects people across the world differently.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the role of money, savings, debt, and investment in individuals' lives.

subject: Social Studies
description: Recognize the importance of setting long-term goals when making financial decisions within the community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the impact of ideas, inventions, and other contributions of prominent figures who lived New Jersey.

subject: Social Studies
description: Examine the qualities of entrepreneurs in a capitalistic society.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare different regions of New Jersey to determine the role that geography, natural resources, climate, transportation, technology, and/or the labor force play in economic opportunities.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the development of different transportation systems impacted the economies of New Jersey and the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how creativity and innovation resulted in scientific achievement and inventions in many cultures during different historical periods.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the role of science and technology in the transition from an agricultural society to an industrial society, and then to the information age.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the development of communications systems has led to increased collaboration and the spread of ideas throughout the United States and the world.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe characteristics of oneself, one's family, and others.

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate an understanding of family roles and traditions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Express individuality and cultural diversity (e.g., through dramatic play).

subject: Social Studies
description: Learn about and respect other cultures within the classroom and community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the impact of European colonization on Native American populations, including the Lenni Lenape of New Jersey.

subject: Social Studies
description: Summarize reasons why various groups, voluntarily and involuntarily, immigrated to New Jersey and America, and describe the challenges they encountered.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the impact of voluntary and involuntary immigration on America's growth as a nation, historically and today.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how key events led to the creation of the United States and the state of New Jersey.

subject: Social Studies
description: Relate key historical documents (i.e., the Mayflower Compact, the Declaration of Independence, the United States Constitution, and the Bill of Rights) to present day government and citizenship.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the civic leadership qualities and historical contributions of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and Benjamin Franklin toward the development of the United States government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the role Governor William Livingston played in the development of New Jersey government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the significance of New Jersey's role in the American Revolution.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the impact of trans-Atlantic slavery on New Jersey, the nation, and individuals.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the influence of Native American groups, including the Lenni Lenape culture, is manifested in different regions of New Jersey.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine how local and state communities have changed over time, and explain the reasons for changes.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how folklore and the actions of famous historical and fictional characters from New Jersey and other regions of the United States contributed to the American national heritage.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how culture is expressed through and influenced by the behavior of people.

subject: Social Studies
description: Trace how the American identity evolved over time.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how various cultural groups have dealt with the conflict between maintaining traditional beliefs and practices and adopting new beliefs and practices.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how stereotyping and prejudice can lead to conflict, using examples from the past and present.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the role of historical symbols, monuments, and holidays and how they affect the American identity.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how an individual's beliefs, values, and traditions may reflect more than one culture.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how experiences and events may be interpreted differently by people with different cultural or individual perspectives.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe why it is important to understand the perspectives of other cultures in an interconnected world.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast forms of governance, belief systems, and family structures among African, European, and Native American groups.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe migration and settlement patterns of Native American groups, and explain how these patterns affected interactions in different regions of the Western Hemisphere.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the world in spatial terms (e.g., longitude, latitude) using historical maps to determine what led to the exploration of new water and land routes.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the impact of science, religion, and technology innovations on European exploration.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why individuals and societies trade, how trade functions, and the role of trade during this period.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast gender roles, religion, values, cultural practices, and political systems of Native American groups.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how interactions among African, European, and Native American groups began a cultural transformation.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the impact of the Colombian Exchange on ecology, agriculture, and culture from different perspectives.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the roles of religious freedom and participatory government in various North American colonies.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how and why early government structures developed, and determine the impact of these early structures on the evolution of American politics and institutions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how demographics (i.e., race, gender, and economic status) affected social, economic, and political opportunities during the Colonial era.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine factors that impacted emigration, settlement patterns, and regional identities of the colonies.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast how the search for natural resources resulted in conflict and cooperation among European colonists and Native American groups in the New World.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare the practice of slavery and indentured servitude in Colonial labor systems.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the system of mercantilism and its impact on the economies of the colonies and European countries.

description: Compare the perspectives of other nations and the United States regarding United States foreign policy.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how and why religious tensions and historic differences in the Middle East have led to international conflicts, and analyze the effectiveness of United States policy and actions in bringing peaceful resolutions to the region.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the reasons for terrorism and the impact that terrorism has had on individuals and government policies, and assess the effectiveness of actions taken by the United States and other nations to prevent terrorism.

subject: Social Studies
description: Examine the impact of media and technology on political and social issues in a global society.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze government efforts to address intellectual property rights, personal privacy, and other ethical issues in science, medicine, and business that arise from the global use of new technologies.

subject: Social Studies
description: Assess from various perspectives the effectiveness with which the United States government addresses economic issues that affect individuals, business, and/or other countries.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why natural resources (i.e., fossil fuels, food, and water) continue to be a source of conflict, and analyze how the United States and other nations have addressed issues concerning the distribution and sustainability of natural resources.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the economic, political, and social impact of new and emerging technologies on individuals and nations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Predict the impact of technology on the global workforce and on entrepreneurship.

subject: Social Studies
description: Assess the impact of international trade, global business organizations, and overseas competition on the United States economy and workforce.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the impact of American culture on other world cultures from multiple perspectives.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how and why technology is transforming access to education and educational practices worldwide.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine past and present factors that led to the widening of the gap between the rich and poor, and evaluate how this has affected individuals and society.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast the social organization, natural resources, and land use of early hunters/gatherers and those who lived in early agrarian societies.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the various migratory patterns of hunters/gatherers that moved from Africa to Eurasia, Australia, and the Americas, and describe the impact of migration on their lives and on the shaping of societies.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the influence of the agricultural revolution (e.g., the impact of food surplus from farming) on population growth and the subsequent development of civilizations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the impact of technological advancements on hunter/gatherer and agrarian societies.

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate an understanding of pre-agricultural and post-agricultural periods in terms of relative length of time.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the development of both written and unwritten languages impacted human understanding, development of culture, and social structure.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how archaeological discoveries are used to develop and enhance understanding of life prior to written records.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how/why different early river valley civilizations developed similar forms of government and legal structures.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the role of slavery in the economic and social structures of early river valley civilizations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the extent to which geography influenced settlement, the development of trade networks, technological innovations, and the sustainability of early river valley civilizations.

description: Compare and contrast physical and political maps of early river valley civilizations and their modern counterparts (i.e., Mesopotamia and Iraq; Ancient Egypt and Modern Egypt; Indus River Valley and Modern Pakistan/India; Ancient China and Modern China), and determine the geopolitical impact of these civilizations, then and now.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how technological advancements led to greater economic specialization, improved weaponry, trade, and the development of a class system in early river valley civilizations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the impact of religion on daily life, government, and culture in various early river valley civilizations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the development of written language transformed all aspects of life in early river valley civilizations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the factors that led to the rise and fall of various early river valley civilizations and determine whether there was a common pattern of growth and decline.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the importance and enduring legacy of the major achievements of the early river valley civilizations over time.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast the methods (i.e., autocratic rule, philosophies, and bureaucratic structures) used by the rulers of Rome, China, and India to control and unify their expanding empires.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast the rights and responsibilities of free men, women, slaves, and foreigners in the political, economic, and social structures of classical civilizations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the foundational concepts and principles of Athenian democracy and the Roman Republic that later influenced the development of the United States Constitution.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare the status (i.e., political, economic, and social) of groups in the Ancient World to those of people today and evaluate how individuals perceived the principles of liberty and equality then and now.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast the American legal system with the legal systems of classical civilizations, and determine the extent to which these early systems influenced our current legal system.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine how geography and the availability of natural resources influenced the development of the political, economic, and cultural systems of each of the classical civilizations and provided motivation for expansion.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how geography and the availability of natural resources led to both the development of Greek city-states and to their decline.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the impact of expanding land and sea trade routes as well as a uniform system of exchange in the Mediterranean World and Asia.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how classical civilizations used technology and innovation to enhance agricultural/ manufacturing output and commerce, to expand military capabilities, to improve life in urban areas, and to allow for greater division of labor.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast social hierarchies in classical civilizations as they relate to power, wealth, and equality.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine common factors that contributed to the decline and fall of the Roman Empire, Gupta India, and Han China.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the importance and enduring legacy of the major achievements of Greece, Rome, India, and China over time.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast the tenets of various world religions that developed in or around this time period (i.e., Buddhism, Christianity, Confucianism, Islam, Judaism, Sikhism, and Taoism), their patterns of expansion, and their responses to the current challenges of globalization.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the extent to which religion, economic issues, and conflict shaped the values and decisions of the classical civilizations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the role of religion and other means rulers used to unify and centrally govern expanding territories with diverse populations.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast the Japanese and European systems of feudalism and the effectiveness of each in promoting social, economic, and political order.

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine how Africa's physical geography and natural resources presented challenges and opportunities for trade, development, and the spread of religion.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why the Arabian Peninsula's physical features and location made it the epicenter of Afro-Eurasian trade and fostered the spread of Islam into Africa, Europe, and Asia.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the motivations for civilizations to modify the environment, determine the positive and negative consequences of environmental changes made during this time period, and relate these changes to current environmental challenges.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the geographies and climates of Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas influenced their economic development and interaction or isolation with other societies.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how and why the interrelationships among improved agricultural production, population growth, urbanization, and commercialization led to the rise of powerful states and kingdoms (i.e., Europe, Asia, Americas).

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the role of religion and economics in shaping each empire's social hierarchy, and evaluate the impact these hierarchical structures had on the lives of various groups of people.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the causes and outcomes of the Crusades from different perspectives, including the perspectives of European political and religious leaders, the crusaders, Jews, Muslims, and traders.

subject: Social Studies
description: Assess the demographic, economic, and religious impact of the plague on Europe.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine which events led to the rise and eventual decline of European feudalism.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze the immediate and long-term impact on China and Europe of the open exchange between Europe and the Yuan (Mongol) Dynasty.

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine the extent to which the Byzantine Empire influenced the Islamic world and western Europe.

subject: Social Studies
description: Evaluate the importance and enduring legacy of the major achievements of the people living Asia, Africa (Islam), Europe and the Americas over time.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare and contrast the motivations for and methods by which various empires (e.g., Ming, Qing, Spanish, Mughal, Ottoman) expanded, and assess why some were more effective than others in maintaining control of their empires.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain major changes in world political boundaries between 1450 and 1770, and assess the extent of European political and military control in Africa, Asia, and the Americas by the mid-18th century.

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies
description: Determine what makes a good rule or law and apply this understanding to rules and laws in your school or community (e.g., bike helmet, recycling).

description: Examine the impact of a local issue by considering the perspectives of different groups, including community members and local officials.

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies
description: Communicate with students from various countries about common issues of public concern and possible solutions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Plan and participate in an advocacy project to inform others about environmental issues at the local or state level and propose possible solutions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Develop and implement a group initiative that addresses an economic issue impacting children.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify actions that are unfair or discriminatory, such as bullying, and propose solutions to address such actions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Deliberate on a public issue affecting an upcoming election, consider opposing arguments, and develop a reasoned conclusion.

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies
description: Collaborate with students from other countries to develop possible solutions to an issue of environmental justice, and present those solutions to relevant national and international governmental and/or nongovernmental organizations.

subject: Social Studies

subject: Social Studies
