subject: Science
description: Inquiry, Reflection, and Social Implications

subject: Science
description: Scientific Inquiry

subject: Science
description: Generate new questions that can be investigated in the laboratory or field.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate the uncertainties or validity of scientific conclusions using an understanding of sources of measurement error, the challenges of controlling variables, accuracy of data analysis, logic of argument, logic of experimental design, and/or the dependence on underlying assumptions.

subject: Science
description: Conduct scientific investigations using appropriate tools and techniques (e.g., selecting an instrument that measures the desired quantity—length, volume, weight, time interval, temperature—with the appropriate level of precision).

subject: Science
description: Identify patterns in data and relate them to theoretical models.

subject: Science
description: Describe a reason for a given conclusion using evidence from an investigation.

subject: Science
description: Predict what would happen if the variables, methods, or timing of an investigation were changed.

subject: Science
description: Use empirical evidence to explain and critique the reasoning used to draw a scientific conclusion or explanation.

subject: Science
description: Design and conduct a systematic scientific investigation that tests a hypothesis. Draw conclusions from data presented in charts or tables.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between scientific explanations that are regarded as current scientific consensus and the emerging questions that active researchers investigate.

subject: Science
description: Scientific Reflection and Social Implications

subject: Science
description: Critique whether or not specific questions can be answered through scientific investigations.

subject: Science
description: Identify and critique arguments about personal or societal issues based on scientific evidence.

subject: Science
description: Develop an understanding of a scientific concept by accessing information from multiple sources. Evaluate the scientific accuracy and significance of the information.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate scientific explanations in a peer review process or discussion format.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate the future career and occupational prospects of science fields.

subject: Science
description: Critique solutions to problems, given criteria and scientific constraints.

subject: Science
description: Identify scientific tradeoffs in design decisions and choose among alternative solutions.

subject: Science
description: Describe the distinctions between scientific theories, laws, hypotheses, and observations.

subject: Science
description: Explain the progression of ideas and explanations that leads to science theories that are part of the current scientific consensus or core knowledge.

subject: Science
description: Apply science principles or scientific data to anticipate effects of technological design decisions.

subject: Science
description: Analyze how science and society interact from a historical, political, economic, or social perspective.

subject: Science
description: Organization and Development of Living Systems

subject: Science
description: Cells (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between living and nonliving systems. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the importance of both water and the element carbon to cells. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe growth and development in terms of increase in cell number, cell size, and/or cell products. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain how the systems in a multicellular organism work together to support the organism. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast how different organisms accomplish similar functions (e.g., obtain oxygen for respiration, and excrete waste). (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Cell Function (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe how organisms sustain life by obtaining, transporting, transforming, releasing, and eliminating matter and energy. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the effect of limiting food to developing cells. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Plants as Producers (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the significance of carbon in organic molecules. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the origins of plant mass. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Predict what would happen to plants growing in low carbon dioxide atmospheres. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain how the roots of specific plants grow. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Animals as Consumers (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Classify different organisms based on how they obtain energy for growth and development. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain how an organism obtains energy from the food it consumes. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Common Elements (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Recognize the six most common elements in organic molecules (C, H, N, O, P, S). (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Identify the most common complex molecules that make up living organisms. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Predict what would happen if essential elements were withheld from developing cells. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Transformation of Matter and Energy in Cells

subject: Science
description: Explain how cells transform energy (ultimately obtained from the sun) from one form to another through the processes of photosynthesis and respiration. Identify the reactants and products in the general reaction of photosynthesis.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the transformation of matter and energy during photosynthesis and respiration.

subject: Science
description: Explain cell division, growth, and development as a consequence of an increase in cell number, cell size, and/or cell products.

subject: Science
description: Cell Differentiation

subject: Science
description: Describe how, through cell division, cells can become specialized for specific function.

subject: Science
description: Predict what would happen if the cells from one part of a developing embryo were transplanted to another part of the embryo.

subject: Science
description: Organic Molecules

subject: Science
description: Explain how carbon can join to other carbon atoms in chains and rings to form large and complex molecules.

subject: Science
description: Recognize the six most common elements in organic molecules (C, H, N, O, P, S).

subject: Science
description: Describe the composition of the four major categories of organic molecules (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids).

subject: Science
description: Explain the general structure and primary functions of the major complex organic molecules that compose living organisms.

subject: Science
description: Describe how dehydration and hydrolysis relate to organic molecules.

subject: Science
description: Proteins

subject: Science
description: Explain the role of enzymes and other proteins in biochemical functions (e.g., the protein hemoglobin carries oxygen in some organisms, digestive enzymes, and hormones).

subject: Science
description: Propose how moving an organism to a new environment may influence its ability to survive and predict the possible impact of this type of transfer.

subject: Science
description: Maintaining Environmental Stability

subject: Science
description: Describe how cells function in a narrow range of physical conditions, such as temperature and pH (acidity), to perform life functions.

subject: Science
description: Describe how the maintenance of a relatively stable internal environment is required for the continuation of life.

subject: Science
description: Explain how stability is challenged by changing physical, chemical, and environmental conditions as well as the presence of disease agents.

subject: Science
description: Homeostasis

subject: Science
description: Identify the general functions of the major systems of the human body (digestion, respiration, reproduction, circulation, excretion, protection from disease, and movement, control, and coordination) and describe ways that these systems interact with each other.

subject: Science
description: Describe how human body systems maintain relatively constant internal conditions (temperature, acidity, and blood sugar).

subject: Science
description: Explain how human organ systems help maintain human health.

subject: Science
description: Compare the structure and function of a human body system or subsystem to a nonliving system (e.g., human joints to hinges, enzyme and substrate to interlocking puzzle pieces).

subject: Science
description: Cell Specialization

subject: Science
description: Explain that living things can be classified based on structural, embryological, and molecular (relatedness of DNA sequence) evidence.

subject: Science
description: Describe how various organisms have developed different specializations to accomplish a particular function and yet the end result is the same (e.g., excreting nitrogenous wastes in animals, obtaining oxygen for respiration).

subject: Science
description: Explain how different organisms accomplish the same result using different structural specializations (gills vs. lungs vs. membranes).

subject: Science
description: Analyze the relationships among organisms based on their shared physical, biochemical, genetic, and cellular characteristics and functional processes.

subject: Science
description: Explain how cellular respiration is important for the production of ATP (build on aerobic vs. anaerobic).

subject: Science
description: Recognize and describe that both living and nonliving things are composed of compounds, which are themselves made up of elements joined by energy-containing bonds, such as those in ATP.

subject: Science
description: Explain that some structures in the modern eukaryotic cell developed from early prokaryotes, such as mitochondria, and in plants, chloroplasts.

subject: Science
description: Describe the structures of viruses and bacteria.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that while viruses lack cellular structure, they have the genetic material to invade living cells.

subject: Science
description: Living Organism Composition

subject: Science
description: Recognize and explain that macromolecules such as lipids contain high energy bonds.

subject: Science
description: Explain how major systems and processes work together in animals and plants, including relationships between organelles, cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms. Relate these to molecular functions.

subject: Science
description: Describe how energy is transferred and transformed from the Sun to energy-rich molecules during photosynthesis.

subject: Science
description: Describe how individual cells break down energy-rich molecules to provide energy for cell functions.

subject: Science
description: Energy Transfer

subject: Science
description: Explain the interrelated nature of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in terms of ATP synthesis and degradation.

subject: Science
description: Relate plant structures and functions to the process of photosynthesis and respiration.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast plant and animal cells.

subject: Science
description: Explain the role of cell membranes as a highly selective barrier (diffusion, osmosis, and active transport).

subject: Science
description: Relate cell parts/organelles to their function.

subject: Science
description: Internal/External Cell Regulation

subject: Science
description: Explain that the regulatory and behavioral responses of an organism to external stimuli occur in order to maintain both short- and long-term equilibrium.

subject: Science
description: Explain that complex interactions among the different kinds of molecules in the cell cause distinct cycles of activities, such as growth and division. Note that cell behavior can also be affected by molecules from other parts of the organism, such as hormones. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Recognize and explain that communication and/or interaction are required between cells to coordinate their diverse activities. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Explain how higher levels of organization result from specific complex interactions of smaller units and that their maintenance requires a constant input of energy as well as new material. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Analyze the body's response to medical interventions such as organ transplants, medicines, and inoculations. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Interdependence of Living Systems and the Environment

subject: Science
description: Populations, Communities, and Ecosystems (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Provide examples of a population, community, and ecosystem. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Relationships Among Organisms (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe common relationships among organisms and provide examples of producer/consumer, predator/prey, or parasite/host relationship. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe common ecological relationships between and among species and their environments (competition, territory, carrying capacity, natural balance, population, dependence, survival, and other biotic and abiotic factors). (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the role of decomposers in the transfer of energy in an ecosystem. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain how two organisms can be mutually beneficial and how that can lead to interdependency. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Factors Influencing Ecosystems (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Identify the factors in an ecosystem that influence fluctuations in population size. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between the living (biotic) and nonliving (abiotic) components of an ecosystem. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain how biotic and abiotic factors cycle in an ecosystem (water, carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen). (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Predict how changes in one population might affect other populations based upon their relationships in a food web. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Human Impact on Ecosystems (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Recognize that, and describe how, human beings are part of Earth's ecosystems. Note that human activities can deliberately or inadvertently alter the equilibrium in ecosystems. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Photosynthesis and Respiration

subject: Science
description: Describe how organisms acquire energy directly or indirectly from sunlight.

subject: Science
description: Illustrate and describe the energy conversions that occur during photosynthesis and respiration.

subject: Science
description: Recognize the equations for photosynthesis and respiration and identify the reactants and products for both.

subject: Science
description: Explain how living organisms gain and use mass through the processes of photosynthesis and respiration.

subject: Science
description: Write the chemical equation for photosynthesis and cellular respiration and explain in words what they mean.

subject: Science
description: Summarize the process of photosynthesis.

subject: Science
description: Ecosystems

subject: Science
description: Identify how energy is stored in an ecosystem.

subject: Science
description: Describe energy transfer through an ecosystem, accounting for energy lost to the environment as heat.

subject: Science
description: Draw the flow of energy through an ecosystem. Predict changes in the food web when one or more organisms are removed.

subject: Science
description: Element Recombination

subject: Science
description: Use a food web to identify and distinguish producers, consumers, and decomposers and explain the transfer of energy through trophic levels.

subject: Science
description: Describe environmental processes (e.g., the carbon and nitrogen cycles) and their role in processing matter crucial for sustaining life.

subject: Science
description: Changes in Ecosystems

subject: Science
description: Describe ecosystem stability. Understand that if a disaster such as flood or fire occurs, the damaged ecosystem is likely to recover in stages of succession that eventually result in a system similar to the original one.

subject: Science
description: Recognize and describe that a great diversity of species increases the chance that at least some living organisms will survive in the face of cataclysmic changes in the environment.

subject: Science
description: Examine the negative impact of human activities.

subject: Science
description: Human Impact

subject: Science
description: Describe the greenhouse effect and list possible causes.

subject: Science
description: List the possible causes and consequences of global warming.

subject: Science
description: Populations

subject: Science
description: Graph changes in population growth, given a data table.

subject: Science
description: Explain the influences that affect population growth.

subject: Science
description: Predict the consequences of an invading organism on the survival of other organisms.

subject: Science
description: Environmental Factors

subject: Science
description: Describe different reproductive strategies employed by various organisms and explain their advantages and disadvantages.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that and describe how the physical or chemical environment may influence the rate, extent, and nature of population dynamics within ecosystems.

subject: Science
description: Graph an example of exponential growth. Then show the population leveling off at the carrying capacity of the environment.

subject: Science
description: Diagram and describe the stages of the life cycle for a human disease-causing organism. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Genetics

subject: Science
description: Reproduction (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the differences between sexual and asexual reproduction. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of sexual vs. asexual reproduction. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Heredity and Environment (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain that the traits of an individual are influenced by both the environment and the genetics of the individual. Acquired traits are not inherited; only genetic traits are inherited. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Genetics and Inherited Traits

subject: Science
description: Draw and label a homologous chromosome pair with heterozygous alleles highlighting a particular gene location.

subject: Science
description: Explain that the information passed from parents to offspring is transmitted by means of genes that are coded in DNA molecules. These genes contain the information for the production of proteins.

subject: Science
description: Differentiate between dominant, recessive, codominant, polygenic, and sex-linked traits.

subject: Science
description: Explain the genetic basis for Mendel's laws of segregation and independent assortment.

subject: Science
description: Determine the genotype and phenotype of monohybrid crosses using a Punnett Square.

subject: Science
description: DNA

subject: Science
description: Show that when mutations occur in sex cells, they can be passed on to offspring (inherited mutations), but if they occur in other cells, they can be passed on to descendant cells only (noninherited mutations).

subject: Science
description: Recognize that every species has its own characteristic DNA sequence.

subject: Science
description: Describe the structure and function of DNA.

subject: Science
description: Predict the consequences that changes in the DNA composition of particular genes may have on an organism (e.g., sickle cell anemia, other).

subject: Science
description: Propose possible effects (on the genes) of exposing an organism to radiation and toxic chemicals.

subject: Science
description: DNA, RNA, and Protein Synthesis

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate how the genetic information in DNA molecules provides instructions for assembling protein molecules and that this is virtually the same mechanism for all life forms.

subject: Science
description: Describe the processes of replication, transcription, and translation and how they relate to each other in molecular biology.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that genetic engineering techniques provide great potential and responsibilities.

subject: Science
description: Explain how recombinant DNA technology allows scientists to analyze the structure and function of genes. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Cell Division – Mitosis and Meiosis

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the processes of cell division (mitosis and meiosis), particularly as those processes relate to production of new cells and to passing on genetic information between generations.

subject: Science
description: Explain why only mutations occurring in gametes (sex cells) can be passed on to offspring.

subject: Science
description: Explain how it might be possible to identify genetic defects from just a karyotype of a few cells.

subject: Science
description: Explain that the sorting and recombination of genes in sexual reproduction result in a great variety of possible gene combinations from the offspring of two parents.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that genetic variation can occur from such processes as crossing over, jumping genes, and deletion and duplication of genes.

subject: Science
description: Predict how mutations may be transferred to progeny.

subject: Science
description: Explain that cellular differentiation results from gene expression and/or environmental influence (e.g., metamorphosis, nutrition).

subject: Science
description: Genetic Variation

subject: Science
description: Describe how inserting, deleting, or substituting DNA segments can alter a gene. Recognize that an altered gene may be passed on to every cell that develops from it and that the resulting features may help, harm, or have little or no effect on the offspring's success in its environment.

subject: Science
description: Explain that gene mutation in a cell can result in uncontrolled cell division called cancer. Also know that exposure of cells to certain chemicals and radiation increases mutations and thus increases the chance of cancer.

subject: Science
description: Explain how mutations in the DNA sequence of a gene may be silent or result in phenotypic change in an organism and in its offspring.

subject: Science
description: Recombinant DNA (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Explain how recombinant DNA technology allows scientists to analyze the structure and function of genes. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of human manipulation of DNA. (recommended)

subject: Science

description: Describe how natural selection provides a mechanism for evolution.

subject: Science

subject: Science
description: Explain how a new species or variety originates through the evolutionary process of natural selection.

subject: Science
description: Explain how natural selection leads to organisms that are well suited for the environment (differential survival and reproduction of chance inherited variants, depending upon environmental conditions).

subject: Science
description: Explain, using examples, how the fossil record, comparative anatomy, and other evidence supports the theory of evolution.

subject: Science
description: Illustrate how genetic variation is preserved or eliminated from a population through natural selection (evolution) resulting in biodiversity.

subject: Science
description: Molecular Evidence

subject: Science

subject: Science
description: Explain that the degree of kinship between organisms or species can be estimated from the similarity of their DNA and protein sequences.

subject: Science
description: Trace the relationship between environmental changes and changes in the gene pool, such as genetic drift and isolation of subpopulations.

subject: Science
description: Interpret a cladogram or phylogenetic tree showing evolutionary relationships among organisms. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Natural Selection

subject: Science
description: Explain how natural selection acts on individuals, but it is populations that evolve. Relate genetic mutations and genetic variety produced by sexual reproduction to diversity within a given population.

subject: Science
description: Describe the role of geographic isolation in speciation.

subject: Science
description: Give examples of ways in which genetic variation and environmental factors are causes of evolution and the diversity of organisms.

subject: Science
description: Explain how evolution through natural selection can result in changes in biodiversity.

subject: Science
description: Explain how changes at the gene level are the foundation for changes in populations and eventually the formation of new species.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate and explain how biotechnology can improve a population and species.

subject: Science
description: Inquiry, Reflection, and Social Implications

subject: Science
description: Scientific Inquiry

subject: Science
description: Generate new questions that can be investigated in the laboratory or field.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate the uncertainties or validity of scientific conclusions using an understanding of sources of measurement error, the challenges of controlling variables, accuracy of data analysis, logic of argument, logic of experimental design, and/or the dependence on underlying assumptions.

subject: Science
description: Conduct scientific investigations using appropriate tools and techniques (e.g., selecting an instrument that measures the desired quantity—length, volume, weight, time interval, temperature—with the appropriate level of precision).

subject: Science
description: Identify patterns in data and relate them to theoretical models.

subject: Science
description: Describe a reason for a given conclusion using evidence from an investigation.

subject: Science
description: Predict what would happen if the variables, methods, or timing of an investigation were changed.

subject: Science
description: Based on empirical evidence, explain and critique the reasoning used to draw a scientific conclusion or explanation

subject: Science
description: Design and conduct a systematic scientific investigation that tests a hypothesis. Draw conclusions from data presented in charts or tables.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between scientific explanations that are regarded as current scientific consensus and the emerging questions that active researchers investigate.

subject: Science
description: Scientific Reflection and Social Implications

subject: Science
description: Critique whether or not specific questions can be answered through scientific investigations.

subject: Science
description: Identify and critique arguments about personal or societal issues based on scientific evidence.

subject: Science
description: Develop an understanding of a scientific concept by accessing information from multiple sources. Evaluate the scientific accuracy and significance of the information.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate scientific explanations in a peer review process or discussion format.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate the future career and occupational prospects of science fields.

subject: Science
description: Critique solutions to problems, given criteria and scientific constraints.

subject: Science
description: Identify scientific tradeoffs in design decisions and choose among alternative solutions.

subject: Science
description: Describe the distinctions between scientific theories, laws, hypotheses, and observations.

subject: Science
description: Explain the progression of ideas and explanations that lead to science theories that are part of the current scientific consensus or core knowledge.

subject: Science
description: Apply science principles or scientific data to anticipate effects of technological design decisions.

subject: Science
description: Analyze how science and society interact from a historical, political, economic, or social perspective.

subject: Science

description: Identify the elements necessary for hydrogen bonding (N, O, F).

description: Explain why ionic solids have higher melting points than covalent solids. (For example, NaF has a melting point of 995°C, while water has a melting point of 0° C.)

description: Conservation of Matter (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Draw a picture of the particles of an element or compound as a solid, liquid, and gas. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Rates of Reactions (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Predict how the rate of a chemical reaction will be influenced by changes in concentration, and temperature, pressure. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Explain how the rate of a reaction will depend on concentration, temperature, pressure, and nature of reactant. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Chemical Changes

subject: Science
description: Balance simple chemical equations applying the conservation of matter.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between chemical and physical changes in terms of the properties of the reactants and products.

subject: Science
description: Draw pictures to distinguish the relationships between atoms in physical and chemical changes.

subject: Science
description: Balancing Equations

subject: Science
description: Calculate the mass of a particular compound formed from the masses of starting materials.

subject: Science
description: Identify the limiting reagent when given the masses of more than one reactant.

subject: Science
description: Predict volumes of product gases using initial volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure.

subject: Science
description: Calculate the number of atoms present in a given mass of element.

subject: Science
description: Equilibrium

subject: Science
description: Describe equilibrium shifts in a chemical system caused by changing conditions (Le Chatelier's Principle).

subject: Science
description: Predict shifts in a chemical system caused by changing conditions (Le Chatelier's Principle).

subject: Science
description: Predict the extent reactants are converted to products using the value of the equilibrium constant.

subject: Science
description: Phase Change/Diagrams

subject: Science
description: Compare the energy required to raise the temperature of one gram of aluminum and one gram of water the same number of degrees.

subject: Science
description: Measure, plot, and interpret the graph of the temperature versus time of an ice-water mixture, under slow heating, through melting and boiling.

subject: Science
description: Changes of State

subject: Science
description: Explain why both the melting point and boiling points for water are significantly higher than other small molecules of comparable mass (e.g., ammonia and methane).

subject: Science
description: Explain why freezing is an exothermic change of state.

subject: Science
description: Compare the melting point of covalent compounds based on the strength of IMFs (intermolecular forces).

subject: Science
description: Chemical Bonds — Trends

subject: Science
description: Predict if the bonding between two atoms of different elements will be primarily ionic or covalent.

subject: Science
description: Predict the formula for binary compounds of main group elements.

subject: Science
description: Chemical Bonds

subject: Science
description: Draw Lewis structures for simple compounds.

subject: Science
description: Compare the relative melting point, electrical and thermal conductivity and hardness for ionic, metallic, and covalent compounds.

subject: Science
description: Relate the melting point, hardness, and electrical and thermal conductivity of a substance to its structure.

subject: Science
description: Reduction/Oxidation Reactions

subject: Science
description: Balance half-reactions and describe them as oxidations or reductions.

subject: Science
description: Predict single replacement reactions.

subject: Science
description: Explain oxidation occurring when two different metals are in contact.

subject: Science
description: Calculate the voltage for spontaneous redox reactions from the standard reduction potentials.

subject: Science
description: Identify the reactions occurring at the anode and cathode in an electrochemical cell.

subject: Science
description: Acids and Bases

subject: Science
description: Recognize formulas for common inorganic acids, carboxylic acids, and bases formed from families I and II.

subject: Science
description: Predict products of an acid-base neutralization.

subject: Science
description: Describe tests that can be used to distinguish an acid from a base.

subject: Science
description: Classify various solutions as acidic or basic, given their pH.

subject: Science
description: Explain why lakes with limestone or calcium carbonate experience less adverse effects from acid rain than lakes with granite beds.

subject: Science
description: Brønsted-Lowry

subject: Science
description: Write balanced chemical equations for reactions between acids and bases and perform calculations with balanced equations.

subject: Science
description: Calculate the pH from the hydronium ion or hydroxide ion concentration.

subject: Science
description: Explain why sulfur oxides and nitrogen oxides contribute to acid rain.

subject: Science
description: Identify the Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pairs in an equation. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Carbon Chemistry

subject: Science
description: Draw structural formulas for up to ten carbon chains of simple hydrocarbons.

subject: Science
description: Draw isomers for simple hydrocarbons.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that proteins, starches, and other large biological molecules are polymers.

subject: Science
description: Inquiry, Reflection, and Social Implications

subject: Science
description: Scientific Inquiry

subject: Science
description: Generate new questions that can be investigated in the laboratory or field.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate the uncertainties or validity of scientific conclusions using an understanding of sources of measurement error, the challenges of controlling variables, accuracy of data analysis, logic of argument, logic of experimental design, and/or the dependence on underlying assumptions.

subject: Science
description: Conduct scientific investigations using appropriate tools and techniques (e.g., selecting an instrument that measures the desired quantity—length, volume, weight, time interval, temperature—with the appropriate level of precision).

subject: Science
description: Identify patterns in data and relate them to theoretical models.

subject: Science
description: Describe a reason for a given conclusion using evidence from an investigation.

subject: Science
description: Predict what would happen if the variables, methods, or timing of an investigation were changed.

subject: Science
description: Based on empirical evidence, explain and critique the reasoning used to draw a scientific conclusion or explanation.

subject: Science
description: Design and conduct a systematic scientific investigation that tests a hypothesis. Draw conclusions from data presented in charts or tables.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between scientific explanations that are regarded as current scientific consensus and the emerging questions that active researchers investigate.

subject: Science
description: Scientific Reflection and Social Implications

subject: Science
description: Critique whether or not specific questions can be answered through scientific investigations.

subject: Science
description: Identify and critique arguments about personal or societal issues based on scientific evidence.

subject: Science
description: Develop an understanding of a scientific concept by accessing information from multiple sources. Evaluate the scientific accuracy and significance of the information.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate scientific explanations in a peer review process or discussion format.

subject: Science
description: Evaluate the future career and occupational prospects of science fields.

subject: Science
description: Critique solutions to problems, given criteria and scientific constraints.

subject: Science
description: Identify scientific tradeoffs in design decisions and choose among alternative solutions.

subject: Science
description: Describe the distinctions between scientific theories, laws, hypotheses, and observations.

subject: Science
description: Explain the progression of ideas and explanations that lead to science theories that are part of the current scientific consensus or core knowledge.

subject: Science
description: Apply science principles or scientific data to anticipate effects of technological design decisions.

subject: Science
description: Analyze how science and society interact from a historical, political, economic, or social perspective.

subject: Science
description: Earth Systems

subject: Science
description: Earth Systems Overview

subject: Science
description: Explain why the Earth is essentially a closed system in terms of matter.

subject: Science
description: Analyze the interactions between the major systems (geosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere) that make up the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Explain, using specific examples, how a change in one system affects other Earth systems.

subject: Science
description: Energy in Earth Systems

subject: Science
description: Describe the Earth's principal sources of internal and external energy (e.g., radioactive decay, gravity, solar energy).

subject: Science
description: Identify differences in the origin and use of renewable (e.g., solar, wind, water, biomass) and nonrenewable (e.g., fossil fuels, nuclear [U-235]) sources of energy.

subject: Science
description: Describe natural processes in which heat transfer in the Earth occurs by conduction, convection, and radiation.

subject: Science
description: Identify the main sources of energy to the climate system.

subject: Science
description: Explain how energy changes form through Earth systems.

subject: Science
description: Explain how elements exist in different compounds and states as they move from one reservoir to another.

subject: Science
description: Biogeochemical Cycles

subject: Science
description: Explain how carbon exists in different forms such as limestone (rock), carbon dioxide (gas), carbonic acid (water), and animals (life) within Earth systems and how those forms can be beneficial or harmful to humans.

subject: Science
description: Explain why small amounts of some chemical forms may be beneficial for life but are poisonous in large quantities (e.g., dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico, Lake Nyos in Africa, fluoride in drinking water).

subject: Science
description: Explain how the nitrogen cycle is part of the Earth system.

subject: Science
description: Explain how carbon moves through the Earth system (including the geosphere) and how it may benefit (e.g., improve soils for agriculture) or harm (e.g., act as a pollutant) society.

subject: Science
description: Resources and Human Impacts on Earth Systems

subject: Science
description: Describe renewable and nonrenewable sources of energy for human consumption (electricity, fuels), compare their effects on the environment, and include overall costs and benefits.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the impact of human activities on the environment (e.g., deforestation, air pollution, coral reef destruction) can be understood through the analysis of interactions between the four Earth systems.

subject: Science
description: Explain ozone depletion in the stratosphere and methods to slow human activities to reduce ozone depletion.

subject: Science
description: Describe the life cycle of a product, including the resources, production, packaging, transportation, disposal, and pollution.

subject: Science
description: Solid Earth

subject: Science
description: Landforms and Soils (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the origin of Michigan landforms. Describe and identify surface features using maps and satellite images. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain how physical and chemical weathering leads to erosion and the formation of soils and sediments. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe how coastal features are formed by wave erosion and deposition. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Rocks and Minerals (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Identify common rock-forming minerals (quartz, feldspar, biotite, calcite, hornblende). (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Identify common igneous (granite, basalt, andesite, obsidian, pumice), metamorphic (schist, gneiss, marble, slate, quartzite), and sedimentary (sandstone, limestone, shale, conglomerate) rocks and describe the processes that change one kind of rock to another. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Basic Plate Tectonics (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe geologic, paleontologic, and paleoclimatalogic evidence that indicates Africa and South America were once part of a single continent.

subject: Science
description: Describe the three types of plate boundaries (divergent, convergent, and transform) and geographic features associated with them (e.g., continental rifts and mid-ocean ridges, volcanic and island arcs, deep-sea trenches, transform faults).

subject: Science
description: Describe the three major types of volcanoes (shield volcano, stratovolcano, and cinder cones) and their relationship to the Ring of Fire.

subject: Science
description: Advanced Rock Cycle

subject: Science
description: Discriminate between igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks and describe the processes that change one kind of rock into another.

subject: Science
description: Explain the relationship between the rock cycle and plate tectonics theory in regard to the origins of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the size and shape of grains in a sedimentary rock indicate the environment of formation (including climate) and deposition.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the crystal sizes of igneous rocks indicate the rate of cooling and whether the rock is extrusive or intrusive.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the texture (foliated, nonfoliated) of metamorphic rock can indicate whether it has experienced regional or contact metamorphism.

subject: Science
description: Interior of the Earth

subject: Science
description: Describe the interior of the Earth (in terms of crust, mantle, and inner and outer cores) and where the magnetic field of the Earth is generated.

subject: Science
description: Explain how scientists infer that the Earth has interior layers with discernable properties using patterns of primary (P) and secondary (S) seismic wave arrivals.

subject: Science
description: Describe the differences between oceanic and continental crust (including density, age, composition).

subject: Science
description: Explain the uncertainties associated with models of the interior of the Earth and how these models are validated.

subject: Science
description: Plate Tectonics Theory

subject: Science
description: Explain how plate tectonics accounts for the features and processes (sea floor spreading, mid-ocean ridges, subduction zones, earthquakes and volcanoes, mountain ranges) that occur on or near the Earth's surface.

subject: Science
description: Explain why tectonic plates move using the concept of heat flowing through mantle convection, coupled with the cooling and sinking of aging ocean plates that result from their increased density.

subject: Science
description: Describe the motion history of geologic features (e.g., plates, Hawaii) using equations relating rate, time, and distance.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish plate boundaries by the pattern of depth and magnitude of earthquakes.

subject: Science
description: Predict the temperature distribution in the lithosphere as a function of distance from the mid-ocean ridge and how it relates to ocean depth. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Describe how the direction and rate of movement for the North American plate has affected the local climate over the last 600 million years. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Earthquakes and Volcanoes

subject: Science
description: Use the distribution of earthquakes and volcanoes to locate and determine the types of plate boundaries.

subject: Science
description: Describe how the sizes of earthquakes and volcanoes are measured or characterized.

subject: Science
description: Describe the effects of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions on humans.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the chemical composition of magmas relates to plate tectonics and affects the geometry, structure, and explosivity of volcanoes.

subject: Science
description: Explain how volcanoes change the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and other Earth systems.

subject: Science
description: Explain why fences are offset after an earthquake, using the elastic rebound theory.

subject: Science
description: Fluid Earth

subject: Science
description: Water Cycle (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe that the water cycle includes evaporation, transpiration, condensation, precipitation, infiltration, surface runoff, groundwater, and absorption. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Analyze the flow of water between the elements of a watershed, including surface features (lakes, streams, rivers, wetlands) and groundwater. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the river and stream types, features, and process including cycles of flooding, erosion, and deposition as they occur naturally and as they are impacted by land use decisions. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the types, process, and beneficial functions of wetlands.

subject: Science
description: Weather and the Atmosphere (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the composition and layers of the atmosphere. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the difference between weather and climate. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the differences between fog and dew formation and cloud formation. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe relative humidity in terms of the moisture content of the air and the moisture capacity of the air and how these depend on the temperature. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe conditions associated with frontal boundaries (cold, warm, stationary, and occluded). (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the characteristics and movement across North America of the major air masses and the jet stream. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Interpret a weather map and describe present weather conditions and predict changes in weather over 24 hours. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the primary causes of seasons. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Identify major global wind belts (trade winds, prevailing westerlies, and polar easterlies) and that their vertical components control the global distribution of rainforests and deserts. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Glaciers (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe how glaciers have affected the Michigan landscape and how the resulting landforms impact our state economy. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain what happens to the lithosphere when an ice sheet is removed. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the formation of the Great Lakes. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Hydrogeology

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast surface water systems (lakes, rivers, streams, wetlands) and groundwater in regard to their relative sizes as Earth's freshwater reservoirs and the dynamics of water movement (inputs and outputs, residence times, sustainability).

subject: Science
description: Explain the features and processes of groundwater systems and how the sustainability of North American aquifers has changed in recent history (e.g., the past 100 years) qualitatively using the concepts of recharge, residence time, inputs, and outputs.

subject: Science
description: Explain how water quality in both groundwater and surface systems is impacted by land use decisions.

subject: Science
description: Oceans and Climate

subject: Science
description: Describe the major causes for the ocean's surface and deep water currents, including the prevailing winds, the Coriolis effect, unequal heating of the earth, changes in water temperature and salinity in high latitudes, and basin shape.

subject: Science
description: Explain how interactions between the oceans and the atmosphere influence global and regional climate. Include the major concepts of heat transfer by ocean currents, thermohaline circulation, boundary currents, evaporation, precipitation, climatic zones, and the ocean as a major CO<sub>2</sub> reservoir.

subject: Science
description: Explain the dynamics (including ocean-atmosphere interactions) of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and its effect on continental climates.

subject: Science
description: Identify factors affecting seawater density and salinity and describe how density affects oceanic layering and currents.

subject: Science
description: Explain the differences between maritime and continental climates with regard to oceanic currents.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the Coriolis effect controls oceanic circulation.

subject: Science
description: Explain how El Niño affects economies (e.g., in South America). (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Severe Weather

subject: Science
description: Describe the various conditions of formation associated with severe weather (thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, floods, waves, and drought).

subject: Science
description: Describe the damage resulting from, and the social impact of thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, and floods.

subject: Science
description: Describe severe weather and flood safety and mitigation.

subject: Science
description: Describe the seasonal variations in severe weather.

subject: Science
description: Describe conditions associated with frontal boundaries that result in severe weather (thunderstorms, tornadoes, and hurricanes).

subject: Science
description: Describe how mountains, frontal wedging (including dry lines), convection, and convergence form clouds and precipitation.

subject: Science
description: Explain the process of adiabatic cooling and adiabatic temperature changes to the formation of clouds.

subject: Science
description: The Earth in Space and Time

subject: Science
description: Sky Observations (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the motions of various celestial bodies and some effects of those motions. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain the primary cause of seasons. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Explain how a light year can be used as a distance unit. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: Describe the position and motion of our solar system in our galaxy. (prerequisite)

subject: Science
description: The Earth in Space

subject: Science
description: Describe the position and motion of our solar system in our galaxy and the overall scale, structure, and age of the universe.

subject: Science
description: Describe how the Big Bang theory accounts for the formation of the universe.

subject: Science
description: Explain how observations of the cosmic microwave background have helped determine the age of the universe.

subject: Science
description: Differentiate between the cosmological and Doppler red shift.

subject: Science
description: The Sun

subject: Science
description: Identify patterns in solar activities (sunspot cycle, solar flares, solar wind).

subject: Science
description: Relate events on the Sun to phenomena such as auroras, disruption of radio and satellite communications, and power grid disturbances.

subject: Science
description: Describe how nuclear fusion produces energy in the Sun.

subject: Science
description: Describe how nuclear fusion and other processes in stars have led to the formation of all the other chemical elements.

subject: Science
description: Stellar Evolution

subject: Science
description: Explain how the Hertzsprung-Russell (H-R) diagram can be used to deduce other parameters (distance).

subject: Science
description: Explain how you can infer the temperature, life span, and mass of a star from its color. Use the H-R diagram to explain the life cycles of stars.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the balance between fusion and gravity controls the evolution of a star (equilibrium).

subject: Science
description: Compare the evolution paths of low-, moderate-, and high-mass stars using the H-R diagram.

subject: Science
description: Earth History and Geologic Time

subject: Science
description: Explain how the solar system formed from a nebula of dust and gas in a spiral arm of the Milky Way Galaxy about 4.6 Ga (billion years ago).

subject: Science
description: Describe the process of radioactive decay and explain how radioactive elements are used to date the rocks that contain them.

subject: Science
description: Relate major events in the history of the Earth to the geologic time scale, including formation of the Earth, formation of an oxygen atmosphere, rise of life, Cretaceous-Tertiary (K-T) and Permian extinctions, and Pleistocene ice age.

subject: Science
description: Describe how index fossils can be used to determine time sequence.

subject: Science
description: Geologic Dating

subject: Science
description: Determine the approximate age of a sample, when given the half-life of a radioactive substance (in graph or tabular form) along with the ratio of daughter to parent substances present in the sample.

subject: Science
description: Explain why C-14 can be used to date a 40,000 year old tree, but U-Pb cannot.

subject: Science
description: Identify a sequence of geologic events using relative-age dating principles.

subject: Science
description: Climate Change

subject: Science
description: Explain the natural mechanism of the greenhouse effect, including comparisons of the major greenhouse gases (water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone).

subject: Science
description: Describe natural mechanisms that could result in significant changes in climate (e.g., major volcanic eruptions, changes in sunlight received by the earth, and meteorite impacts).

subject: Science
description: Analyze the empirical relationship between the emissions of carbon dioxide, atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, and the average global temperature over the past 150 years.

subject: Science
description: Based on evidence of observable changes in recent history and climate change models, explain the consequences of warmer oceans (including the results of increased evaporation, shoreline and estuarine impacts, oceanic algae growth, and coral bleaching) and changing climatic zones (including the adaptive capacity of the biosphere).

subject: Science
description: Based on evidence from historical climate research (e.g. fossils, varves, ice core data) and climate change models, explain how the current melting of polar ice caps can impact the climatic system .

subject: Science
description: Describe geologic evidence that implies climates were significantly colder at times in the geologic record (e.g., geomorphology, striations, and fossils).

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the heat-trapping mechanisms of the major greenhouse gases resulting from emissions (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, fluorocarbons) as well as their abundance and heat- trapping capacity.

subject: Science
description: Use oxygen isotope data to estimate paleotemperature. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Explain the causes of short-term climate changes such as catastrophic volcanic eruptions and impact of solar system objects. (recommended)

subject: Science
description: Predict the global temperature increase by 2100, given data on the annual trends of CO<sub>2</sub> concentration increase. (recommended)

description: Explain how the solar system formed from a nebula of dust and gas in a spiral arm of the Milky Way Galaxy about 4.6 Ga (billion years ago).

subject: Science
description: Describe the process of radioactive decay and explain how radioactive elements are used to date the rocks that contain them.

subject: Science
description: Relate major events in the history of the Earth to the geologic time scale, including formation of the Earth, formation of an oxygen atmosphere, rise of life, Cretaceous-Tertiary (K-T) and Permian extinctions, and Pleistocene ice age.

subject: Science
description: Describe how index fossils can be used to determine time sequence.

subject: Science
description: Climate Change

subject: Science
description: Explain the natural mechanism of the greenhouse effect, including comparisons of the major greenhouse gases (water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone).

subject: Science
description: Describe natural mechanisms that could result in significant changes in climate (e.g., major volcanic eruptions, changes in sunlight received by the earth, and meteorite impacts).

subject: Science
description: Analyze the empirical relationship between the emissions of carbon dioxide, atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, and the average global temperature over the past 150 years.

subject: Science
description: Based on evidence of observable changes in recent history and climate change models, explain the consequences of warmer oceans (including the results of increased evaporation, shoreline and estuarine impacts, oceanic algae growth, and coral bleaching) and changing climatic zones (including the adaptive capacity of the biosphere).

subject: Science
description: Organization and Development of Living Systems

subject: Science
description: Transformation of Matter and Energy in Cells

subject: Science
description: Explain how cells transform energy (ultimately obtained from the sun) from one form to another through the processes of photosynthesis and respiration. Identify the reactants and products in the general reaction of photosynthesis.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the transformation of matter and energy during photosynthesis and respiration.

subject: Science
description: Explain cell division, growth, and development as a consequence of an increase in cell number, cell size, and/or cell products.

subject: Science
description: Organic Molecules

subject: Science
description: Explain how carbon can join to other carbon atoms in chains and rings to form large and complex molecules.

subject: Science
description: Recognize the six most common elements in organic molecules (C, H, N, O, P, S).

subject: Science
description: Describe the composition of the four major categories of organic molecules (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids).

subject: Science
description: Explain the general structure and primary functions of the major complex organic molecules that compose living organisms.

subject: Science
description: Describe how dehydration and hydrolysis relate to organic molecules.

subject: Science
description: Maintaining Environmental Stability

subject: Science
description: Describe how cells function in a narrow range of physical conditions, such as temperature and pH (acidity), to perform life functions.

subject: Science
description: Describe how the maintenance of a relatively stable internal environment is required for the continuation of life.

subject: Science
description: Explain how stability is challenged by changing physical, chemical, and environmental conditions as well as the presence of disease agents.

subject: Science
description: Cell Specialization

subject: Science
description: Explain that living things can be classified based on structural, embryological, and molecular (relatedness of DNA sequence) evidence.

subject: Science
description: Describe how various organisms have developed different specializations to accomplish a particular function and yet the end result is the same (e.g., excreting nitrogenous wastes in animals, obtaining oxygen for respiration).

subject: Science
description: Explain how different organisms accomplish the same result using different structural specializations (gills vs. lungs vs. membranes).

subject: Science
description: Living Organism Composition

subject: Science
description: Recognize and explain that macromolecules such as lipids contain high energy bonds.

subject: Science
description: Explain how major systems and processes work together in animals and plants, including relationships between organelles, cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms. Relate these to molecular functions.

subject: Science
description: Describe how energy is transferred and transformed from the Sun to energy-rich molecules during photosynthesis.

subject: Science
description: Describe how individual cells break down energy-rich molecules to provide energy for cell functions.

subject: Science
description: Interdependence of Living Systems and the Environment

subject: Science
description: Photosynthesis and Respiration

subject: Science
description: Describe how organisms acquire energy directly or indirectly from sunlight.

subject: Science
description: Illustrate and describe the energy conversions that occur during photosynthesis and respiration.

subject: Science
description: Recognize the equations for photosynthesis and respiration and identify the reactants and products for both.

subject: Science
description: Explain how living organisms gain and use mass through the processes of photosynthesis and respiration.

subject: Science
description: Ecosystems

subject: Science
description: Identify how energy is stored in an ecosystem.

subject: Science
description: Describe energy transfer through an ecosystem, accounting for energy lost to the environment as heat.

subject: Science
description: Draw the flow of energy through an ecosystem. Predict changes in the food web when one or more organisms are removed.

subject: Science
description: Element Recombination

subject: Science
description: Use a food web to identify and distinguish producers, consumers, and decomposers and explain the transfer of energy through trophic levels.

subject: Science
description: Changes in Ecosystems

subject: Science
description: Describe ecosystem stability. Understand that if a disaster such as flood or fire occurs, the damaged ecosystem is likely to recover in stages of succession that eventually result in a system similar to the original one.

subject: Science
description: Recognize and describe that a great diversity of species increases the chance that at least some living organisms will survive in the face of cataclysmic changes in the environment.

subject: Science
description: Examine the negative impact of human activities.

subject: Science
description: Populations

subject: Science
description: Graph changes in population growth, given a data table.

subject: Science
description: Explain the influences that affect population growth.

subject: Science
description: Predict the consequences of an invading organism on the survival of other organisms.

subject: Science
description: Genetics

subject: Science
description: Genetics and Inherited Traits

subject: Science
description: Draw and label a homologous chromosome pair with heterozygous alleles highlighting a particular gene location.

subject: Science
description: Explain that the information passed from parents to offspring is transmitted by means of genes that are coded in DNA molecules. These genes contain the information for the production of proteins.

subject: Science
description: DNA

subject: Science
description: Show that when mutations occur in sex cells, they can be passed on to offspring (inherited mutations), but if they occur in other cells, they can be passed on to descendant cells only (noninherited mutations).

subject: Science
description: Recognize that every species has its own characteristic DNA sequence.

subject: Science
description: Describe the structure and function of DNA.

subject: Science
description: Predict the consequences that changes in the DNA composition of particular genes may have on an organism (e.g., sickle cell anemia, other).

subject: Science
description: Propose possible effects (on the genes) of exposing an organism to radiation and toxic chemicals.

subject: Science
description: Cell Division – Mitosis and Meiosis

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the processes of cell division (mitosis and meiosis), particularly as those processes relate to production of new cells and to passing on genetic information between generations.

subject: Science
description: Explain why only mutations occurring in gametes (sex cells) can be passed on to offspring.

subject: Science
description: Explain how it might be possible to identify genetic defects from just a karyotype of a few cells.

subject: Science
description: Evolution and Biodiversity

subject: Science
description: Theory of Evolution

subject: Science
description: Summarize the major concepts of natural selection (differential survival and reproduction of chance inherited variants, depending on environmental conditions).

subject: Science
description: Describe how natural selection provides a mechanism for evolution.

subject: Science
description: Natural Selection

subject: Science
description: Explain how natural selection acts on individuals, but it is populations that evolve. Relate genetic mutations and genetic variety produced by sexual reproduction to diversity within a given population.

subject: Science
description: Describe the role of geographic isolation in speciation.

subject: Science
description: Give examples of ways in which genetic variation and environmental factors are causes of evolution and the diversity of organisms.

subject: Science
description: Motion of Objects

subject: Science
description: Position - Time

subject: Science
description: Calculate the average speed of an object using the change of position and elapsed time.

subject: Science
description: Represent the velocities for linear and circular motion using motion diagrams (arrows on strobe pictures).

subject: Science
description: Create line graphs using measured values of position and elapsed time.

subject: Science
description: Describe and analyze the motion that a position-time graph represents, given the graph.

subject: Science
description: Describe and classify various motions in a plane as one dimensional, two dimensional, circular, or periodic.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between rotation and revolution and describe and contrast the two speeds of an object like the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Velocity - Time

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between the variables of distance, displacement, speed, velocity, and acceleration.

subject: Science
description: Use the change of speed and elapsed time to calculate the average acceleration for linear motion.

subject: Science
description: Describe and analyze the motion that a velocity-time graph represents, given the graph.

subject: Science
description: State that uniform circular motion involves acceleration without a change in speed.

subject: Science
description: Forces and Motion

subject: Science
description: Basic Forces in Nature

subject: Science
description: Identify the force(s) acting between objects in "direct contact" or at a distance.

subject: Science
description: Net Forces

subject: Science
description: Identify the magnitude and direction of everyday forces (e.g., wind, tension in ropes, pushes and pulls, weight).

subject: Science
description: Compare work done in different situations.

subject: Science
description: Calculate the net force acting on an object.

subject: Science
description: Newton's Third Law

subject: Science
description: Identify the action and reaction force from examples of forces in everyday situations (e.g., book on a table, walking across the floor, pushing open a door).

subject: Science
description: Forces and Acceleration

subject: Science
description: Predict the change in motion of an object acted on by several forces.

subject: Science
description: Identify forces acting on objects moving with constant velocity (e.g., cars on a highway).

subject: Science
description: Solve problems involving force, mass, and acceleration in linear motion (Newton's second law).

subject: Science
description: Identify the force(s) acting on objects moving with uniform circular motion (e.g., a car on a circular track, satellites in orbit).

subject: Science
description: Gravitational Interactions

subject: Science
description: Explain earth-moon interactions (orbital motion) in terms of forces.

subject: Science
description: Predict how the gravitational force between objects changes when the distance between them changes.

subject: Science
description: Explain how your weight on Earth could be different from your weight on another planet.

subject: Science
description: Electric Charges

subject: Science
description: Predict how the electric force between charged objects varies when the distance between them and/or the magnitude of charges change.

subject: Science
description: Explain why acquiring a large excess static charge (e.g., pulling off a wool cap, touching a Van de Graaff generator, combing) affects your hair.

subject: Science
description: Forms of Energy and Energy Transformations

subject: Science
description: Energy Transfer

subject: Science
description: Account for and represent energy into and out of systems using energy transfer diagrams.

subject: Science
description: Explain instances of energy transfer by waves and objects in everyday activities (e.g., why the ground gets warm during the day, how you hear a distant sound, why it hurts when you are hit by a baseball).

subject: Science
description: Energy Transformation

subject: Science
description: Account for and represent energy transfer and transformation in complex processes (interactions).

subject: Science
description: Name devices that transform specific types of energy into other types (e.g., a device that transforms electricity into motion).

subject: Science
description: Explain how energy is conserved in common systems (e.g., light incident on a transparent material, light incident on a leaf, mechanical energy in a collision).

subject: Science
description: Explain why all the stored energy in gasoline does not transform to mechanical energy of a vehicle

subject: Science
description: Kinetic and Potential Energy

subject: Science
description: Identify the form of energy in given situations (e.g., moving objects, stretched springs, rocks on cliffs, energy in food).

subject: Science
description: Describe the transformation between potential and kinetic energy in simple mechanical systems (e.g., pendulums, roller coasters, ski lifts).

subject: Science
description: Explain why all mechanical systems require an external energy source to maintain their motion.

subject: Science
description: Wave Characteristics

subject: Science
description: Describe specific mechanical waves (e.g., on a demonstration spring, on the ocean) in terms of wavelength, amplitude, frequency, and speed.

subject: Science
description: Identify everyday examples of transverse and compression (longitudinal) waves.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast transverse and compression (longitudinal) waves in terms of wavelength, amplitude, and frequency.

subject: Science
description: Mechanical Wave Propagation

subject: Science
description: Identify everyday examples of energy transfer by waves and their sources.

subject: Science
description: Explain why an object (e.g., fishing bobber) does not move forward as a wave passes under it.

subject: Science
description: Provide evidence to support the claim that sound is energy transferred by a wave, not energy transferred by particles.

subject: Science
description: Explain how waves propagate from vibrating sources and why the intensity decreases with the square of the distance from a point source.

subject: Science
description: Explain why everyone in a classroom can hear one person speaking, but why an amplification system is often used in the rear of a large concert auditorium.

subject: Science
description: Electromagnetic Waves

subject: Science
description: Identify the different regions on the electromagnetic spectrum and compare them in terms of wavelength, frequency, and energy.

subject: Science
description: Explain why radio waves can travel through space, but sound waves cannot.

subject: Science
description: Explain why there is a delay between the time we send a radio message to astronauts on the moon and when they receive it.

subject: Science
description: Explain why we see a distant event before we hear it (e.g., lightning before thunder, exploding fireworks before the boom).

subject: Science
description: Wave Behavior - Reflection and Refraction

subject: Science
description: Draw ray diagrams to indicate how light reflects off objects or refracts into transparent media.

subject: Science
description: Predict the path of reflected light from flat, curved, or rough surfaces (e.g., flat and curved mirrors, painted walls, paper).

subject: Science
description: Nature of Light

subject: Science
description: Identify the principle involved when you see a transparent object (e.g., straw, piece of glass) in a clear liquid.

subject: Science
description: Explain how various materials reflect, absorb, or transmit light in different ways.

subject: Science
description: Explain why the image of the Sun appears reddish at sunrise and sunset.

subject: Science
description: Current Electricity - Circuits

subject: Science
description: Describe the energy transformations when electrical energy is produced and transferred to homes and businesses.

subject: Science
description: Identify common household devices that transform electrical energy to other forms of energy, and describe the type of energy transformation.

subject: Science
description: Given diagrams of many different possible connections of electric circuit elements, identify complete circuits, open circuits, and short circuits and explain the reasons for the classification.

subject: Science
description: Discriminate between voltage, resistance, and current as they apply to an electric circuit.

subject: Science
description: Nuclear Reactions

subject: Science
description: Describe peaceful technological applications of nuclear fission and radioactive decay.

subject: Science
description: Describe possible problems caused by exposure to prolonged radioactive decay.

subject: Science
description: Explain how stars, including our Sun, produce huge amounts of energy (e.g., visible, infrared, ultraviolet light).

subject: Science
description: Molecules in Motion

subject: Science
description: Describe conduction in terms of molecules bumping into each other to transfer energy. Explain why there is better conduction in solids and liquids than gases.

subject: Science
description: Describe the various states of matter in terms of the motion and arrangement of the molecules (atoms) making up the substance.

subject: Science
description: Energy Transfer and Conservation

subject: Science
description: Heating Impacts

subject: Science
description: Describe how heat is conducted in a solid.

subject: Science
description: Describe melting on a molecular level.

subject: Science
description: Endothermic and Exothermic Reactions

subject: Science
description: Use the terms endothermic and exothermic correctly to describe chemical reactions in the laboratory.

subject: Science
description: Explain why chemical reactions will either release or absorb energy.

description: Properties of Matter

subject: Science
description: Nomenclature

subject: Science
description: Name simple binary compounds using their formulae.

subject: Science
description: Given the name, write the formula of simple binary compounds.

subject: Science
description: Properties of Substances

subject: Science
description: Recognize that substances that are solid at room temperature have stronger attractive forces than liquids at room temperature, which have stronger attractive forces than gases at room temperature.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that solids have a more ordered, regular arrangement of their particles than liquids and that liquids are more ordered than gases.

subject: Science
description: Atomic Structure

subject: Science
description: Identify the location, relative mass, and charge for electrons, protons, and neutrons.

subject: Science
description: Describe the atom as mostly empty space with an extremely small, dense nucleus consisting of the protons and neutrons and an electron cloud surrounding the nucleus.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that protons repel each other and that a strong force needs to be present to keep the nucleus intact.

subject: Science
description: Give the number of electrons and protons present if the fluoride ion has a -1 charge.

subject: Science
description: Periodic Table

subject: Science
description: Identify elements with similar chemical and physical properties using the periodic table.

description: Neutral Atoms, Ions, and Isotopes

subject: Science
description: List the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons for any given ion or isotope.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that an element always contains the same number of protons.

subject: Science
description: Chemical Changes

subject: Science
description: Balance simple chemical equations applying the conservation of matter.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between chemical and physical changes in terms of the properties of the reactants and products.

subject: Science
description: Draw pictures to distinguish the relationships between atoms in physical and chemical changes.

subject: Science
description: Compare the energy required to raise the temperature of one gram of aluminum and one gram of water the same number of degrees.

subject: Science
description: Measure, plot, and interpret the graph of the temperature versus time of an ice-water mixture, under slow heating, through melting and boiling.
