description: Chemical Bonds - Trends

subject: Science
description: Predict if the bonding between two atoms of different elements will be primarily ionic or covalent.

subject: Science
description: Predict the formula for binary compounds of main group elements.

subject: Science
description: Recognize formulas for common inorganic acids, carboxylic acids, and bases formed from families I and II.

subject: Science
description: Predict products of an acid-base neutralization.

subject: Science
description: Describe tests that can be used to distinguish an acid from a base.

subject: Science
description: Classify various solutions as acidic or basic, given their pH.

subject: Science
description: Explain why lakes with limestone or calcium carbonate experience less adverse effects from acid rain than lakes with granite beds.

subject: Science
description: Draw structural formulas for up to ten carbon chains of simple hydrocarbons.

subject: Science
description: Draw isomers for simple hydrocarbons.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that proteins, starches, and other large biological molecules are polymers.

description: Draw conclusions from sets of data from multiple trials of a scientific investigation to draw conclusions.

subject: Science
description: Use multiple sources of information to evaluate strengths and weaknesses of claims, arguments, or data.

subject: Science
description: Reflecting on knowledge is the application of scientific knowledge to new and different situations. Reflecting on knowledge requires careful analysis of evidence that guides decision-making and the application of science throughout history and within society.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate scientific concepts through various illustrations, performances, models, exhibits, and activities.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate scientific concepts through various illustrations, performances, models, exhibits, and activities.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that science investigations are done more than one time.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate scientific concepts through various illustrations, performances, models, exhibits, and activities.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that when a science investigation is done the way it was done before, similar results are expected.

subject: Science
description: Use evidence when communicating scientific ideas.

subject: Science
description: Use data/samples as evidence to separate fact from opinion.

subject: Science

subject: Science

subject: Science
description: Position- A position of an object can be described by locating the object relative to other objects or a background. The description of the motion of an object from one observer's view may be different from that reported from a different observer's view.

subject: Science
description: Compare the position of an object (for example: above, below, in front of, behind, on) in relation to other objects around it.

subject: Science
description: Describe the motion of an object (for example: away from or closer to) from different observers' views.

subject: Science
description: Gravity- Earth pulls down on all objects with a force called gravity. With very few exceptions, objects fall to the ground no matter where the object is on the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Observe how objects fall toward the earth.

subject: Science
description: Identify the force that pulls objects towards the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Force- A force is either a push or a pull. The motion of objects can be changed by forces. The size of the change is related to the size of the force. The change is also related to the weight (mass) of the object on which the force is being exerted. When an object does not move in response to a force, it is because another force is being applied by the environment.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate pushes and pulls.

subject: Science
description: Observe that objects initially at rest will move in the direction of the push or pull.

subject: Science
description: Observe how pushes and pulls can change the speed or direction of moving objects.

subject: Science
description: Observe how shape (for example: cone, cylinder, sphere), size, and weight of an object can affect motion.

subject: Science
description: Describe how a push or a pull is a force.

subject: Science
description: Relate a change in motion of an object to the force that caused the change of motion.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate how the change in motion of an object is related to the strength of the force acting upon the object and to the mass of the object.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate when an object does not move in response to a force, it is because another force is acting on it.

subject: Science
description: Speed- An object is in motion when its position is changing. The speed of an object is defined by how far it travels divided by the amount of time it took to travel that far.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the motion of objects in terms of direction.

subject: Science
description: Identify changes in motion (change direction, speeding up, slowing down).

subject: Science
description: Calculate the speed of an object based on the distance it travels divided by the amount of time it took to travel that distance.

subject: Science
description: Force Interactions- Some forces between objects act when the objects are in direct contact (touching), such as friction and air resistance, or when they are not in direct contact (not touching), such as magnetic force, electrical force, and gravitational force.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between contact forces and non-contact forces.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate contact and non-contact forces to change the motion of an object.

subject: Science
description: Force- Forces have a magnitude and direction. Forces can be added. The net force on an object is the sum of all of the forces acting on the object. The speed and/or direction of motion of an object changes when a non-zero net force is applied to it. A balanced force on an object does not change the motion of the object (the object either remains at rest or continues to move at a constant speed in a straight line).

subject: Science
description: Describe what happens when two forces act on an object in the same or opposing directions.

subject: Science
description: Describe how constant motion is the result of balanced (zero net) forces.

subject: Science
description: Describe how changes in the motion of objects are caused by a non-zero net (unbalanced) force.

subject: Science
description: Relate the size of change in motion to the strength of unbalanced forces and the mass of the object.

subject: Science
description: Speed- Motion can be described by a change in position relative to a point of reference. The motion of an object can be described by its speed and the direction it is moving. The position and speed of an object can be measured and graphed as a function of time.

subject: Science
description: Explain the motion of an object relative to its point of reference.

subject: Science
description: Describe the motion of an object in terms of distance, time and direction, as the object moves, and in relationship to other objects.

subject: Science
description: Illustrate how motion can be measured and represented on a graph.

subject: Science
description: Physical Properties- All objects and substances have physical properties that can be measured.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate the ability to sort objects according to observable attributes such as color, shape, size, sinking or floating.

subject: Science
description: Describe objects and substances according to their properties (color, size, shape, texture, hardness, liquid or solid, sinking or floating).

subject: Science
description: Measure the length of objects using rulers (centimeters) and meter sticks (meters).

subject: Science
description: Measure the volume of liquids using common measuring tools (measuring cups, measuring spoons).

subject: Science
description: Compare the weight of objects using balances.

subject: Science
description: Measure the weight (spring scale) and mass (balances in grams or kilograms) of objects.

subject: Science
description: Measure volumes of liquids and capacities of containers in milliliters and liters.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate the use of centimeter cubes poured into a container to estimate the container's capacity.

subject: Science
description: States of Matter- Matter exists in several different states: solids, liquids and gases. Each state of matter has unique physical properties. Gases are easily compressed but liquids and solids do not compress easily. Solids have their own particular shapes, but liquids and gases take the shape of the container.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate that water as a solid keeps its own shape (ice).

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate that water as a liquid takes on the shape of various containers.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the states (solids, liquids, gases) of matter.

subject: Science
description: Magnets- Magnets can repel or attract other magnets. Magnets can also attract certain non-magnetic objects at a distance.

subject: Science
description: Identify materials that are attracted by magnets.

subject: Science
description: Observe that like poles of a magnet repel and unlike poles of a magnet attract.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate magnetic field by observing the patterns formed with iron filings using a variety of magnets.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate that non-magnetic objects are affected by the strength of the magnet and the distance away from the magnet.

subject: Science
description: Material Composition- Some objects are composed of a single substance, while other objects are composed of more than one substance.

subject: Science
description: Classify objects as single substances (ice, silver, sugar, salt) or mixtures (salt and pepper, mixed dry beans).

subject: Science
description: Conductive and Reflective Properties- Objects vary to the extent they absorb and reflect light energy and conduct heat and electricity.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate how some materials are heated more than others by light that shines on them.

subject: Science
description: Explain how we need light to see objects: light from a source reflects off objects and enters our eyes.

subject: Science
description: Identify objects that are good conductors or poor conductors of heat and electricity.

subject: Science
description: Chemical Properties- Matter has chemical properties. The understanding of chemical properties helps to explain how new substances are formed.

subject: Science
description: Classify substances by their chemical properties (flammability, pH, acid-base indicators, reactivity).

subject: Science
description: Elements and Compounds- Elements are composed of a single kind of atom that are grouped into families with similar properties on the periodic table. Compounds are composed of two or more different elements. Each element and compound has a unique set of physical and chemical properties such as boiling point, density, color, conductivity, and reactivity.

subject: Science
description: Identify the smallest component that makes up an element.

subject: Science
description: Describe how the elements within the Periodic Table are organized by similar properties into families (highly reactive metals, less reactive metals, highly reactive nonmetals, and some almost completely non-reactive gases).

subject: Science
description: Illustrate the structure of molecules using models or drawings (water, carbon dioxide, salt).

subject: Science
description: List examples of physical and chemical properties of elements and compounds (boiling point, density, color, conductivity, reactivity).

subject: Science
description: Forms of Energy- Heat, electricity, light, and sound are forms of energy.

subject: Science
description: Identify light and sound as forms of energy.

subject: Science
description: Identify heat and electricity as forms of energy.

subject: Science
description: Light Properties- Light travels in straight lines. Shadows result from light not being able to pass through an object. When light travels at an angle from one substance to another (air and water), it changes direction.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate that light travels in a straight line and that shadows are made by placing an object in a path of light.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate what happens to light when it travels from water to air. (straw half in water looks bent).

subject: Science
description: Sound- Vibrating objects produce sound. The pitch of sound varies by changing the rate of vibration.

subject: Science
description: Relate sounds to their sources of vibrations (for example: a musical note produced by a vibrating guitar string, the sounds of a drum made by the vibrating drum head).

subject: Science
description: Distinguish the effect of fast or slow vibrations as pitch.

subject: Science
description: Energy and Temperature- Increasing the temperature of any substance requires the addition of energy.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate how temperature can be increased in a substance by adding energy.

subject: Science
description: Describe heat as the energy produced when substances burn, certain kinds of materials rub against each other, and when electricity flows through wire.

subject: Science
description: Describe how heat is produced through electricity, rubbing, and burning.

subject: Science
description: Electrical Circuits- Electrical circuits transfer electrical energy and produce magnetic fields.

subject: Science
description: Explain how electrical energy is transferred and changed through the use of a simple circuit.

subject: Science
description: Create a simple working electromagnet and explain the conditions necessary to make the electromagnet.

subject: Science
description: Kinetic and Potential Energy- Objects and substances in motion have kinetic energy. Objects and substances may have potential energy due to their relative positions in a system. Gravitational, elastic, and chemical energy are all forms of potential energy.

subject: Science
description: Identify kinetic or potential energy in everyday situations (for example: stretched rubber band, objects in motion, ball on a hill, food energy).

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate the transformation between potential and kinetic energy in simple mechanical systems (for example: roller coasters, pendulums).

subject: Science
description: Energy Transfer- Energy is transferred from a source to a receiver by radiation, conduction, and convection. When energy is transferred from a source to a receiver, the quantity of energy before the transfer is equal to the quantity of energy after the transfer.

subject: Science
description: Explain how different forms of energy can be transferred from one place to another by radiation, conduction, or convection.

subject: Science
description: Illustrate how energy can be transferred while no energy is lost or gained in the transfer.

subject: Science
description: Explain how light energy is transferred to chemical energy through the process of photosynthesis.

subject: Science
description: Waves and Energy-Waves have energy and transfer energy when they interact with matter. Examples of waves include sound waves, seismic waves, waves on water, and light waves.

subject: Science
description: Identify examples of waves, including sound waves, seismic waves, and waves on water.

subject: Science
description: Describe how waves are produced by vibrations in matter.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate how waves transfer energy when they interact with matter (for example: tuning fork in water, waves hitting a beach, earthquake knocking over buildings).

subject: Science
description: Solar Energy Effects- Nuclear reactions take place in the sun producing heat and light. Only a tiny fraction of the light energy from the sun reaches Earth, providing energy to heat the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Identify that nuclear reactions take place in the sun, producing heat and light.

subject: Science
description: Explain how only a tiny fraction of light energy from the sun is transformed to heat energy on Earth.

subject: Science
description: Changes in State- Matter can be changed from one state (liquid, solid, gas) to another and then back again. This may be caused by heating and cooling.

subject: Science
description: Explain how matter can change from one state (liquid, solid, gas) to another by heating and cooling.

subject: Science
description: Changes in State- Matter changing from state to state can be explained by using models which show that matter is composed of tiny particles in motion. When changes of state occur, the atoms and/or molecules are not changed in structure. When the changes in state occur, mass is conserved because matter is not created or destroyed.

subject: Science
description: Describe and illustrate changes in state, in terms of the arrangement and relative motion of the atoms or molecules.

subject: Science
description: Explain how mass is conserved as it changes from state to state in a closed system.

subject: Science
description: Chemical Changes- Chemical changes occur when two elements and/or compounds react and produce new substances. These new substances have different physical and chemical properties than the original elements and/or compounds. During the chemical change, the number and kind of atoms in the reactants are the same as the number and kind of atoms in the products. Mass is conserved during chemical changes. The mass of the reactants is the same as the mass of the products.

subject: Science
description: Identify evidence of chemical change through color, gas formation, solid formation, and temperature change.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the chemical properties of a new substance with the original after a chemical change.

subject: Science
description: Describe the physical properties and chemical properties of the products and reactants in a chemical change.

subject: Science
description: Life Requirements- Organisms have basic needs. Animals and plants need air, water, and food. Plants also require light. Plants and animals use food as a source of energy and as a source of building material for growth and repair.

subject: Science
description: Identify that living things have basic needs.

subject: Science
description: Identify and compare living and nonliving things.

subject: Science
description: Identify the needs of animals.

subject: Science
description: Identify the needs of plants.

subject: Science
description: Determine that plants require air, water, light, and a source of energy and building material for growth and repair.

subject: Science
description: Determine that animals require air, water, and a source of energy and building material for growth and repair.

subject: Science
description: Life Cycles- Plants and animals have life cycles. Both plants and animals begin life and develop into adults, reproduce, and eventually die. The details of this life cycle are different for different organisms.

subject: Science
description: Describe the life cycle of animals including the following stages: egg, young, adult; egg, larva, pupa, adult.

subject: Science
description: Describe the life cycle of familiar flowering plants including the following stages: seed, plant, flower, and fruit.

subject: Science
description: Structures and Functions- Organisms have different structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction.

subject: Science
description: Describe the function of the following plant parts: flower, stem, root and leaf.

subject: Science
description: Identify and compare structures in animals used for controlling body temperature, support, movement, food-getting, and protection (for example: fur, wings, teeth, claws).

subject: Science
description: Classification- Organisms can be classified on the basis of observable characteristics.

subject: Science
description: Classify plants on the basis of observable physical characteristics (roots, leaves, stems, and flowers).

subject: Science
description: Classify animals on the basis of observable physical characteristics (backbone, skin, shell, limbs, scales).

subject: Science
description: Animal Systems- Multicellular organisms may have specialized systems that perform functions which serve the needs of the organism.

subject: Science
description: Identify the general purpose of selected animal systems (digestive, circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, nervous, excretory, and reproductive).

subject: Science
description: Explain how animal systems (digestive, circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, nervous, excretory, and reproductive) work together to perform selected activities.

subject: Science
description: Producers, Consumers, and Decomposers- All animals, including humans, are consumers that meet their energy by eating other organisms or their products. Consumers break down the structures of the organisms they eat to make the materials they need to grow and function. Decomposers, including bacteria and fungi, use dead organisms or their products to meet their energy needs.

subject: Science
description: Classify organisms (producers, consumers, and decomposers) based on their source of energy for growth and development.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between the ways in which consumers and decomposers obtain energy.

subject: Science
description: Cell Functions- All organisms are composed of cells, from one cell to many cells. In multicellular organisms, specialized cells perform specialized functions. Organs and organ systems are composed of cells, and function to serve the needs of cells for food, air, and waste removal. The way in which cells function is similar in all living organisms.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that all organisms are composed of cells (single cell organisms, multicellular organisms).

subject: Science
description: Explain how cells make up different body tissues, organs, and organ systems.

subject: Science
description: Describe how cells in all multicellular organisms are specialized to take in nutrients, which they use to provide energy for the work that cells do and to make the materials that a cell or organism needs.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that cells function in a similar way in all organisms.

subject: Science
description: Growth and Development- Following fertilization, cell division produces a small cluster of cells that then differentiate by appearance and function to form the basic tissue of an embryo.

subject: Science
description: Describe growth and development in terms of increase of cell number and/or cell size.

subject: Science
description: Examine how through cell division, cells can become specialized for specific functions.

subject: Science
description: Photosynthesis- Plants are producers; they use the energy from light to make sugar molecules from the atoms of carbon dioxide and water. Plants use these sugars along with minerals from the soil to form fats, proteins, and carbohydrates. These products can be used immediately, incorporated into the cells of a plant as the plant grows, or stored for later use.

subject: Science
description: Recognize the need for light to provide energy for the production of carbohydrates, proteins and fats.

subject: Science
description: Explain that carbon dioxide and water are used to produce carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

subject: Science
description: Describe evidence that plants make, use and store food.

subject: Science
description: Observable Characteristics- Plants and animals share many, but not all, characteristics of their parents.

subject: Science
description: Identify characteristics (for example: body coverings, beak shape, number of legs, body parts) that are passed on from parents to young.

subject: Science
description: Classify young animals based on characteristics that are passed on from parents (for example: dogs/puppies, cats/kittens, cows/calves, chicken/chicks).

subject: Science
description: Identify characteristics of plants (for example: leaf shape, flower type, color, size) that are passed on from parents to young.

subject: Science
description: Inherited and Acquired Traits - The characteristics of organisms are influenced by heredity and environment. For some characteristics, inheritance is more important; for other characteristics, interactions with the environment are more important.

subject: Science
description: Explain that the traits of an individual are influenced by both the environment and the genetics of the individual.

subject: Science
description: Distinguish between inherited and acquired traits.

subject: Science
description: Reproduction- Reproduction is a characteristic of all living systems; because no individual organism lives forever, reproduction is essential to the continuation of every species. Some organisms reproduce asexually. Other organisms reproduce sexually.

subject: Science
description: Compare how characteristics of living things are passed on through generations, both asexually and sexually.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the advantages and disadvantages of sexual vs. asexual reproduction.

subject: Science
description: Environmental Adaptation- Different kinds of organisms have characteristics that help them to live in different environments.

subject: Science
description: Relate characteristics and functions of observable parts in a variety of plants that allow them to live in their environment (for example: leaf shape, thorns, odor, color).

subject: Science
description: Relate characteristics and functions of observable body parts to the ability of animals to live in their environment(for example: sharp teeth, claws, color, body covers).

subject: Science
description: Survival- Individuals of the same kind differ in their characteristics, and sometimes the differences give individuals an advantage in surviving and reproducing.

subject: Science
description: Identify individual differences (for example: color, leg length, size, wing size) in organisms of the same kind.

subject: Science
description: Identify how variations in physical characteristics of individual organisms give them an advantage for survival and reproduction.

subject: Science
description: Species Adaptation and Survival- Species with certain traits are more likely than others to survive and have offspring in particular environments. When an environment changes, the advantage or disadvantage of the species' characteristics can change. Extinction of a species occurs when the environment changes and the characteristics of a species are insufficient to allow survival.

subject: Science
description: Explain how behavioral characteristics (adaptation, instinct, learning, habit) of animals help them to survive in their environment.

subject: Science
description: Describe the physical characteristics (traits) of organisms that help them survive in their environment.

subject: Science
description: Describe how fossils provide evidence about how living things and environmental conditions have changed.

subject: Science
description: Analyze the relationship of environmental change and catastrophic events (for example: volcanic eruption, floods, asteroid impacts, tsunami) to species extinction.

subject: Science
description: Relationships Among Organisms- Similarities among organisms are found in anatomical features, which can be used to infer the degree of relatedness among organisms. In classifying organisms, biologists consider details of internal and external structures to be more important than behavior or general appearance.

subject: Science
description: Relate degree of similarity in anatomical features to the classification of contemporary organisms.

subject: Science
description: Interactions- Organisms interact in various ways including providing food and shelter to one another. Some interactions are helpful: others are harmful to the organism and other organisms.

subject: Science
description: Identify organisms as part of a food chain or food web.

subject: Science
description: Changed Environment Effects- When the environment changes, some plants and animals survive to reproduce; others die or move to new locations.

subject: Science
description: Explain how environmental changes can produce a change in the food web.

subject: Science
description: Interactions of Organisms- Organisms of one species form a population. Populations of different organisms interact and form communities. Living communities and nonliving factors that interact with them form ecosystems.

subject: Science
description: List examples of populations, communities, and ecosystems including the Great Lakes region.

subject: Science
description: Relationships of Organisms- Two types of organisms may interact with one another in several ways: They may be in a producer/consumer, predator/ prey, or parasite/host relationship. Some organisms may scavenge or decompose another. Relationships may be competitive or mutually beneficial. Some species have become so adapted to each other that neither could survive without the other.

subject: Science
description: Describe common patterns of relationships between and among populations (competition, parasitism, symbiosis, predator/prey).

subject: Science
description: Explain how two populations of organisms can be mutually beneficial and how that can lead to interdependency.

subject: Science
description: Predict how changes in one population might affect other populations based upon their relationships in the food web.

subject: Science
description: Biotic and Abiotic Factors- The number of organisms and populations an ecosystem can support depends on the biotic (living) resources available and abiotic (nonliving) factors, such as quality of light and water, range of temperatures and soil composition.

subject: Science
description: Identify the living (biotic) and nonliving (abiotic) components of an ecosystem.

subject: Science
description: Identify the factors in an ecosystem that influence changes in population size.

subject: Science
description: Environmental Impact of Organisms- All organisms (including humans) cause change in the environment where they live. Some of the changes are harmful to the organism or other organisms, whereas others are helpful.

subject: Science
description: Describe how human beings are part of the ecosystem of the Earth and that human activity can purposefully, or accidentally, alter the balance in ecosystems.

subject: Science
description: Predict possible consequences of overpopulation of organisms, including humans, (for example: species extinction, resource depletion, climate change, pollution).

subject: Science
description: Earth Materials- Earth materials that occur in nature include rocks, minerals, soils, water, and the gases of the atmosphere. Some Earth materials have properties which sustain plant and animal life.

subject: Science
description: Identify Earth materials (air, water, soil) that are used to grow plants.

subject: Science
description: Describe how Earth materials contribute to the growth of plant and animal life.

subject: Science
description: Recognize and describe different types of earth materials (mineral, rock, clay, boulder, gravel, sand, soil).

subject: Science
description: Recognize that rocks are made up of minerals.

subject: Science
description: Surface Changes- The surface of Earth changes. Some changes are due to slow processes, such as erosion and weathering, and some changes are due to rapid processes, such as landslides, volcanic eruptions, and earthquakes.

subject: Science
description: Describe the major landforms of the surface of the Earth (mountains, plains, plateaus, valleys, hills).

subject: Science
description: Identify and describe natural causes of change in the Earth's surface (erosion, glaciers, volcanoes, landslides, and earthquakes).

subject: Science
description: Using Earth Materials- Some Earth materials have properties that make them useful either in their present form or designed and modified to solve human problems. They can enhance the quality of life as in the case of materials used for building or fuels used for heating and transportation.

subject: Science
description: Identify Earth materials used to construct some common objects (for example: bricks, buildings, roads, glass).

subject: Science
description: Describe how materials taken from the Earth can be used as fuels for heating and transportation.

subject: Science
description: Soil- Soils consist of weathered rocks and decomposed organic materials from dead plants, animals, and bacteria. Soils are often found in layers with each having a different chemical composition and texture.

subject: Science
description: Explain how physical and chemical weathering lead to erosion and the formation of soils and sediments.

subject: Science
description: Explain how waves, wind, water, and glacier movement, shape and reshape the land surface of the Earth by eroding rock in some areas and depositing sediments in other areas.

subject: Science
description: Describe how soil is a mixture, made up of weather eroded rock and decomposed organic material.

subject: Science
description: Compare different soil samples based on particle size and texture.

subject: Science
description: Rock Formation- Rocks and rock formations bear evidence of the minerals, materials, temperature/pressure conditions, and forces that created them.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the formation of rock types (igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary) and demonstrate the similarities and differences using the rock cycle model.

subject: Science
description: Plate Tectonics- The lithospheric plates of the Earth constantly move, resulting in major geological events, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and mountain building.

subject: Science
description: Explain plate tectonic movement and how the lithospheric plates move centimeters each year.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate how major geological events (earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, mountain building) result from these plate motions.

subject: Science
description: Describe layers of the Earth as a lithosphere (crust and upper mantle), convecting mantle, and dense metallic core.

subject: Science
description: Magnetic Field of Earth- Earth as a whole has a magnetic field that is detectable at the surface with a compass.

subject: Science
description: Describe the Earth as a magnet and compare the magnetic properties of the Earth to that of a natural or man-made magnet.

subject: Science
description: Explain how a compass works using the magnetic field of the Earth, and how a compass is used for navigation on land and sea.

subject: Science
description: Solar Energy- The sun warms the land, air and water and helps plants grow.

subject: Science
description: Identify the sun as the most important source of heat which warms the land, air, and water of the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate the importance of sunlight and warmth in plant growth.

subject: Science
description: Weather- Weather changes from day to day and over the seasons.

subject: Science
description: Compare daily changes in the weather related to temperature (cold, hot, warm, cool); cloud cover (cloudy, partly cloudy, foggy) precipitation (rain, snow, hail, freezing rain); wind (breezy, windy, calm).

subject: Science
description: Describe and compare weather related to the four seasons in terms of temperature, cloud cover, precipitation, and wind.

subject: Science
description: Describe severe weather events.

subject: Science
description: Describe precautions that should be taken for human safety during severe weather conditions (thunderstorms, lightning, tornadoes, high winds, blizzards, hurricanes).

subject: Science
description: Weather Measurement- Scientists use tools for observing, recording, and predicting weather changes.

subject: Science
description: Identify the tools that might be used to measure temperature, precipitation, cloud cover and wind.

subject: Science
description: Observe and collect data of weather conditions over a period of time.

subject: Science
description: Natural Resources- The supply of many natural resources is limited. Humans have devised methods for extending their use of natural resources through recycling, reuse, and renewal.

subject: Science
description: Identify natural resources (metals, fuels, fresh water, farmland, and forests).

subject: Science
description: Classify renewable (fresh water, farmland, forests) and non-renewable (fuels, metals) resources.

subject: Science
description: Describe ways humans are protecting, extending, and restoring resources (recycle, reuse, reduce, renewal).

subject: Science
description: Recognize that paper, metal, glass, and some plastics can be recycled.

subject: Science
description: Human Impact- Humans depend on their natural and constructed environment. Humans change environments in ways that are helpful or harmful for themselves and other organisms.

subject: Science
description: Describe ways humans are dependent on the natural environment (forests, water, clean air, earth materials) and constructed environments (homes, neighborhoods, shopping malls, factories, and industry).

subject: Science
description: Describe helpful or harmful effects of humans on the environment (garbage, habitat destruction, land management, renewable and non-renewable resources).

subject: Science
description: Seasons- Seasons result from annual variations in the intensity of sunlight and length of day due to the tilt of the axis of the Earth relative to the plane of its yearly orbit around the sun.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate using a model, seasons as the result of variations in the intensity of sunlight caused by the tilt of the Earth on its axis, and revolution around the sun.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the revolution of the Earth around the sun defines a year.

subject: Science
description: Solar Energy- The sun is the major source of energy for phenomena on the surface of the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Demonstrate, using a model or drawing, the relationship between the warming by the sun of the Earth and the water cycle as it applies to the atmosphere (evaporation, water vapor, warm air rising, cooling, condensation, clouds).

subject: Science
description: Describe the relationship between the warming of the atmosphere of the Earth by the sun and convection within the atmosphere and oceans.

subject: Science
description: Describe how the warming of the Earth by the sun produces winds and ocean currents.

subject: Science
description: Human Consequences- Human activities have changed the land, oceans, and atmosphere of the Earth resulting in the reduction of the number and variety of wild plants and animals sometimes causing extinction of species.

subject: Science
description: Explain how human activities (surface mining, deforestation, overpopulation, construction and urban development, farming, dams, landfills, and restoring natural areas) change the surface of the Earth and affect the survival of organisms.

subject: Science
description: Describe the origins of pollution in the atmosphere, geosphere, and hydrosphere, (car exhaust, industrial emissions, acid rain, and natural sources), and how pollution impacts habitats, climatic change, threatens or endangers species.

subject: Science
description: Weather and Climate- Global patterns of atmospheric and oceanic movement influence weather and climate.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the difference and relationship between climate and weather.

subject: Science
description: Describe how different weather occurs due to the constant motion of the atmosphere from the energy of the sun reaching the surface of the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the temperature of the oceans affects the different climates on Earth because water in the oceans holds a large amount of heat.

subject: Science
description: Describe weather conditions associated with frontal boundaries (cold, warm, stationary, and occluded) and the movement of major air masses and the jet stream across North America using a weather map.

subject: Science
description: Water Cycle- Water circulates through the four spheres of the Earth in what is known as the "water cycle."

subject: Science
description: Explain the water cycle and describe how evaporation, transpiration, condensation, cloud formation, precipitation, infiltration, surface runoff, ground water, and absorption occur within the cycle.

subject: Science
description: Analyze the flow of water between the components of a watershed, including surface features (lakes, streams, rivers, wetlands) and groundwater.

subject: Science
description: Water- Water is a natural resource and is found under the ground, on the surface of the earth, and in the sky. It exists in three states (liquid, solid, gas) and can go back and forth from one form to another.

subject: Science
description: Identify water sources (wells, springs, lakes, rivers, oceans).

subject: Science
description: Identify household uses of water (drinking, cleaning, food preparation).

subject: Science
description: Describe the properties (visible, flowing, melting, dew) of water as a liquid (lakes, rivers, streams, oceans).

subject: Science
description: Describe the properties (hard, visible, freezing, ice) of water as a solid (ice, snow, iceberg, sleet, hail).

subject: Science
description: Water Movement- Water moves in predictable patterns.

subject: Science
description: Describe how rain collects on the surface of the Earth and flows downhill into bodies of water (streams, rivers, lakes, oceans) or into the ground.

subject: Science
description: Describe the major bodies of water on the Earth's surface (lakes, ponds, oceans, rivers, streams).

subject: Science
description: Atmosphere- The atmosphere is a mixture of nitrogen, oxygen and trace gases that include water vapor. The atmosphere has different physical and chemical composition at different elevations.

subject: Science
description: Describe the atmosphere as a mixture of gases.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the composition of the atmosphere at different elevations.

subject: Science
description: Characteristics of Objects in the Sky- Common objects in the sky have observable characteristics.

subject: Science
description: Identify common objects in the sky, such as the sun and the moon.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast the characteristics of the sun, moon and Earth, including relative distances and abilities to support life.

subject: Science
description: Patterns of Objects in the Sky- Common objects in the sky have observable characteristics and predictable patterns of movement.

subject: Science
description: Describe the orbit of the Earth around the sun as it defines a year.

subject: Science
description: Explain that the spin of the Earth creates day and night.

subject: Science
description: Describe the motion of the moon around the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Explain how the visible shape of the moon follows a predictable cycle which takes approximately one month.

subject: Science
description: Describe the apparent movement of the sun and moon across the sky through day/night and the seasons.

subject: Science
description: Fossils- Fossils provide evidence about the plants and animals that lived long ago and the nature of the environment at that time.

subject: Science
description: Explain how fossils provide evidence of the history of the Earth.

subject: Science
description: Compare and contrast life forms found in fossils and organisms that exist today.

subject: Science
description: Solar System- The sun is the central and largest body in our solar system. Earth is the third planet from the sun in a system that includes other planets and their moons, as well as smaller objects, such as asteroids and comets.

subject: Science
description: Design a model that describes the position and relationship of the planets and other objects (comets and asteroids) to the sun.

subject: Science
description: Solar System Motion- Gravity is the force that keeps most objects in the solar system in regular and predictable motion.

subject: Science
description: Describe the motion of planets and moons in terms of rotation on axis and orbits due to gravity.

subject: Science
description: Explain moon phases as they relate to the position of the moon in its orbit around the Earth, resulting in the amount of observable reflected light.

subject: Science
description: Recognize that nighttime objects (stars and constellations) and the sun appear to move because the Earth rotates on its axis and orbits the sun.

subject: Science
description: Explain lunar and solar eclipses based on the relative positions of the Earth, moon, and sun, and the orbit of the moon.

subject: Science
description: Explain the tides of the oceans as they relate to the gravitational pull and orbit of the moon.

subject: Science
description: Fossils- Fossils provide important evidence of how life and environmental conditions have changed in a given location.

subject: Science
description: Explain how rocks and fossils are used to understand the age and geological history of the earth (timelines and relative dating, rock layers).

subject: Science
description: Geologic Time- Earth processes seen today (erosion, mountain building, and glacier movement) make possible the measurement of geologic time through methods such as observing rock sequences and using fossils to correlate the sequences at various locations.

subject: Science
description: Explain how Earth processes (erosion, mountain building, and glacier movement) are used for the measurement of geologic time through observing rock layers.

subject: Science
description: Describe how fossils provide important evidence of how life and environmental conditions have changed.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish among yesterday, today, tomorrow.

subject: Social Studies
description: Create a timeline using events from their own lives (e.g., birth, crawling, walking, loss of first tooth, first day of school).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify the beginning, middle, and end of historical narratives or stories.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe ways people learn about the past (e.g., photos, artifacts, diaries, stories, videos).

subject: Social Studies
description: Recognize that maps and globes represent places.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use environmental directions or positional words (up/down, in/out, above/below) to identify significant locations in the classroom.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify and describe places in the immediate environment (e.g., classroom, home, playground).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe ways people use the environment to meet human needs and wants (e.g., food, shelter, clothing).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify our country's flag as an important symbol of the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why people do not have the right to do whatever they want (e.g., to promote fairness, ensure the common good, maintain safety).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe fair ways for groups to make decisions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe situations in which they demonstrated self-discipline and individual responsibility (e.g., caring for a pet, completing chores, following school rules, working in a group, taking turns).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe economic wants they have experienced.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between goods and services.

subject: Social Studies
description: Recognize situations in which people trade.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify classroom issues.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use simple graphs to explain information about a classroom issue.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare their viewpoint about a classroom issue with the viewpoint of another person.

subject: Social Studies
description: Express a position on a classroom issue.

subject: Social Studies
description: Develop and implement an action plan to address or inform others about a public issue.

subject: Social Studies
description: Participate in projects to help or inform others.

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate chronological thinking by distinguishing among past, present, and future using family or school events.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use a calendar to distinguish among days, weeks, and months.

subject: Social Studies
description: Investigate a family history for at least two generations, identifying various members and their connections in order to tell a narrative about family life.

subject: Social Studies
description: Retell in sequence important ideas and details from stories about families or schools.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use historical records and artifacts (e.g., photos, diaries, oral histories, and videos) to draw possible conclusions about family or school life in the past.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare life today with life in the past using the criteria of family, school, jobs, or communication.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify the events or people celebrated during United States national holidays and why we celebrate them (e.g., Independence Day, Constitution Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day; Presidents' Day).

subject: Social Studies
description: Construct simple maps of the classroom to demonstrate aerial perspective.

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of places that have absolute locations (e.g., home address, school address).

subject: Social Studies
description: Use personal directions (left, right, front, back) to describe the relative location of significant places in the school environment.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between landmasses and bodies of water using maps and globes.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between physical (e.g., clouds, trees, weather) and human (e.g., buildings, playgrounds, sidewalks) characteristics of places.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the unifying characteristics and/or boundaries of different school regions (e.g., playground, reading corner, library, restroom).

subject: Social Studies
description: Use components of culture (e.g., foods, language, religion, traditions) to describe diversity in family life.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe ways in which people modify (e.g., cutting down trees, building roads) and adapt to the environment (e.g., clothing, housing, transportation).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify some reasons for rules in school (e.g., provide order, predictability, and safety).

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of the use of power with authority in school (e.g., principal, teacher or bus driver enforcing school rules).

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of the use of power without authority in school (e.g., types of bullying, taking cuts in line).

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how decisions can be made or how conflicts might be resolved in fair and just ways (e.g., majority rules).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify important symbols of the United States of America (e.g., Statue of Liberty, Uncle Sam, White House, Bald Eagle).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe some responsibilities people have at home and at school (e.g., taking care of oneself, respect for the rights of others, following rules, getting along with others).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify situations in which people act as good citizens in the school community (e.g., thoughtful and effective participation in the school decisions, respect for the rights of others, respect for rule of law, voting, volunteering, compassion, courage, honesty).

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between producers and consumers of goods and services.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe ways in which families consume goods and services.

subject: Social Studies
description: Using examples, explain why people cannot have everything they want (scarcity) and describe how people respond (choice).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe reasons why people voluntarily trade.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe ways in which people earn money (e.g., providing goods and services to others, jobs).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how money simplifies trade.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify public issues in the school community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use graphic data to analyze information about a public issue in the school community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify alternative resolutions to a public issue in the school community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Express a position on a public policy issue in the school community and justify the position with a reasoned argument.

subject: Social Studies
description: Develop and implement an action plan to address or inform others about a public issue.

subject: Social Studies
description: Participate in projects to help or inform others.

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate chronological thinking by distinguishing among years and decades using a timeline of local community events.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why descriptions of the same event in the local community can be different.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use an example to describe the role of the individual in creating history.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe changes in the local community over time (e.g., types of businesses, architecture and landscape, jobs, transportation, population).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify a problem in a community's past and describe how it was resolved.

subject: Social Studies
description: Construct a historical narrative about the history of the local community from a variety of sources (e.g., data gathered from local residents, artifacts, photographs).

subject: Social Studies
description: Construct maps of the local community that contain symbols, labels, and legends denoting human and natural characteristics of place.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use maps to describe the spatial organization of the local community by applying concepts including relative location and using distance, direction, and scale.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare the physical and human characteristics of the local community with those of another community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the local community is part of a larger region (e.g., county, metropolitan area, state).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe land use in the community (e.g., where people live, where services are provided, where products are made).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the means people create for moving people, goods, and ideas within the local community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use components of culture (e.g., foods, language, religion, traditions) to describe diversity in the local community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Suggest ways people can responsibly interact with the environment in the local community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe positive and negative consequences of changing the physical environment of the local community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why people form governments.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between government action and private action.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how local governments balance individual rights with the common good to solve local community problems.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the Pledge of Allegiance reflects the core democratic value of patriotism.

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of how local governments make, enforce, and interpret laws (ordinances) in the local community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use examples to describe how local government affects the lives of its citizens.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify services commonly provided by local governments (e.g., police, fire departments, schools, libraries, parks).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify ways citizens participate in community decisions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between personal and civic responsibilities and explain why they are important in community life.

subject: Social Studies
description: Design and participate in community improvement projects that help or inform others. (See P4.2.2)

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify the opportunity cost involved in a consumer decision.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify businesses in the local community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how businesses in the local community meet economic wants of consumers.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the natural, human, and capital resources needed for production of a good or service in a community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use examples to show that people cannot produce everything they want (specialization) and depend on trade with others to meet their wants.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify public issues in the local community that influence the daily lives of its citizens.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use graphic data and other sources to analyze information about a public issue in the local community and evaluate alternative resolutions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of how conflicts over core democratic values lead people to differ on resolutions to a public policy issue in the local community.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compose a statement expressing a position on a public policy issue in the local community and justify the position with a reasoned argument.

subject: Social Studies
description: Develop and implement an action plan to address or inform others about a public issue.

subject: Social Studies
description: Participate in projects to help or inform others.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify questions historians ask in examining the past in Michigan (e.g., What happened? When did it happen? Who was involved? How and why did it happen?)

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how historians use primary and secondary sources to answer questions about the past.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the causal relationships between three events in Michigan's past (e.g., Erie Canal, more people came, statehood).

subject: Social Studies
description: Draw upon traditional stories of American Indians (e.g., Anishinaabeg - Ojibway (Chippewa), Odawa (Ottawa), Potawatomi; Menominee; Huron Indians) who lived in Michigan in order to make generalizations about their beliefs.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use informational text and visual data to compare how American Indians and settlers in the early history of Michigan adapted to, used, and modified their environment.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use a variety of sources to describe interactions that occurred between American Indians and the first European explorers and settlers in Michigan.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use a variety of primary and secondary sources to construct a historical narrative about daily life in the early settlements of Michigan (pre-statehood).

subject: Social Studies
description: Use case studies or stories to describe how the ideas or actions of individuals affected the history of Michigan.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how Michigan attained statehood.

subject: Social Studies
description: Create a timeline to sequence early Michigan history (American Indians, exploration, settlement, statehood).

subject: Social Studies
description: Use cardinal directions (north, south, east, west) to describe the relative location of significant places in the immediate environment.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use thematic maps to identify and describe the physical and human characteristics of Michigan.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use a variety of visual materials and data sources to describe ways in which Michigan can be divided into regions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe different regions to which Michigan belongs (e.g., Great Lakes Region, Midwest).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe major kinds of economic activity in Michigan today, such as agriculture (e.g., corn, cherries, dairy), manufacturing (e.g., automobiles, wood products), services and tourism, research and development (e.g., Automation Alley, life sciences corridor, university communities), and explain the factors influencing the location of these economic activities. (E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe diverse groups that have come into a region of Michigan and reasons why they came (push/pull factors). (H)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe some of the current movements of goods, people, jobs or information to, from, or within Michigan and explain reasons for the movements. (E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Use data and current information about the Anishinaabeg and other American Indians living in Michigan today to describe the cultural aspects of modern American Indian life; give an example of how another cultural group in Michigan today has preserved and built upon its cultural heritage.

subject: Social Studies
description: Locate natural resources in Michigan and explain the consequences of their use.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how people adapt to, use, and modify the natural resources of Michigan. (H)

subject: Social Studies
description: Give an example of how Michigan state government fulfills one of the purposes of government (e.g., protecting individual rights, promoting the common good, ensuring equal treatment under the law).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how Michigan state government reflects the principle of representative government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Distinguish between the roles of state and local government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify goods and services provided by the state government and describe how they are funded (e.g., taxes, fees, fines).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify the three branches of state government in Michigan and the powers of each.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how state courts function to resolve conflict.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the purpose of the Michigan Constitution.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify rights (e.g., freedom of speech, freedom of religion, right to own property) and responsibilities of citizenship (e.g., respecting the rights of others, voting, obeying laws).

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how scarcity, opportunity costs, and choices affect what is produced and consumed in Michigan.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify incentives (e.g., sales, tax breaks) that influence economic decisions people make in Michigan.

subject: Social Studies
description: Analyze how Michigan's location and natural resources influenced its economic development (e.g., how waterways and other natural resources have influenced economic activities such as mining, lumbering, automobile manufacturing, and furniture making). (H, G)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how entrepreneurs combine natural, human, and capital resources to produce goods and services in Michigan. (H, G)

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the role of business development in Michigan's economic future.

subject: Social Studies
description: Using a Michigan example, describe how specialization leads to increased interdependence (cherries grown in Michigan are sold in Florida; oranges grown in Florida are sold in Michigan).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify products produced in other countries and consumed by people in Michigan.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify public issues in Michigan that influence the daily lives of its citizens.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use graphic data and other sources to analyze information about a public issue in Michigan and evaluate alternative resolutions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of how conflicts over core democratic values lead people to differ on resolutions to a public policy issue in Michigan.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compose a paragraph expressing a position on a public policy issue in Michigan and justify the position with a reasoned argument.

subject: Social Studies
description: Develop and implement an action plan and know how, when, and where to address or inform others about a public issue.

subject: Social Studies
description: Participate in projects to help or inform others.

subject: Social Studies
description:
Use historical inquiry questions to investigate the development of Michigan's major economic activities (agriculture, mining, manufacturing, lumbering, tourism, technology, and research) from statehood to present. (C, E)
  • What happened?
  • When did it happen?
  • Who was involved?
  • How and why did it happen?
  • How does it relate to other events or issues in the past, in the present, or in the future?
  • What is its significance?

subject: Social Studies
description: Use primary and secondary sources to explain how migration and immigration affected and continue to affect the growth of Michigan. (G)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the relationship between the location of natural resources and the location of industries (after 1837) affected and continues to affect the location and growth of Michigan cities. (G, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Draw upon stories, photos, artifacts, and other primary sources to compare the life of people in towns and cities in Michigan and in the Great Lakes region during a variety of time periods from 1837 to the present (e.g., 1837-1900, 1900-1950, 1950-2000). (G)

subject: Social Studies
description: Use visual data and informational text or primary accounts to compare a major Michigan economic activity today with that same or a related activity in the past. (E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Use a variety of primary and secondary sources to construct a historical narrative about the beginnings of the automobile industry and the labor movement in Michigan. (G, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Use case studies or stories to describe the ideas and actions of individuals involved in the Underground Railroad in Michigan and in the Great Lakes region. (See 8-U4.2.2; 8-U4.3.2; 8-U5.1.5; USHG 7.2.4) (G, C, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe past and current threats to Michigan's natural resources; describe how Michigan worked in the past and continues to work today to protect its natural resources. (G, C, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Create timelines (using decades after 1930) to sequence and describe important events in Michigan history; annotate with connections to the past and impact on the future.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify questions geographers ask in examining the United States (e.g., Where it is? What is it like there? How is it connected to other places?).

subject: Social Studies
description: Use cardinal and intermediate directions to describe the relative location of significant places in the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify and describe the characteristics and purposes (e.g., measure distance, determine relative location, classify a region) of a variety of geographic tools and technologies (e.g., globe, map, satellite image).

subject: Social Studies
description: Use geographic tools and technologies, stories, songs, and pictures to answer geographic questions about the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use maps to describe elevation, climate, and patterns of population density in the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe ways in which the United States can be divided into different regions (e.g., political regions, economic regions, landform regions, vegetation regions).

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare human and physical characteristics of a region to which Michigan belongs (e.g., Great Lakes, Midwest) with those of another region in the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use a case study or story about migration within or to the United States to identify push and pull factors (why they left, why they came) that influenced the migration. (H)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the impact of immigration to the United States on the cultural development of different places or regions of the United States (e.g., forms of shelter, language, food). (H)

subject: Social Studies
description: Assess the positive and negative effects of human activities on the physical environment of the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify questions political scientists ask in examining the United States (e.g., What does government do? What are the basic values and principles of American democracy? What is the relationship of the United States to other nations? What are the roles of the citizen in American democracy?).

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain probable consequences of an absence of government and of rules and laws.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the purposes of government as identified in the Preamble of the Constitution.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the principles of popular sovereignty, rule of law, checks and balances, separation of powers, and individual rights (e.g., freedom of religion, freedom of expression, freedom of press) serve to limit the powers of the federal government as reflected in the Constitution and Bill of Rights.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify situations in which specific rights guaranteed by the Constitution and Bill of Rights are involved (e.g., freedom of religion, freedom of expression, freedom of press).

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of ways the Constitution limits the powers of the federal government (e.g., election of public officers, separation of powers, checks and balances, Bill of Rights).

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of powers granted to the federal government (e.g., coining of money, declaring war) and those reserved for the states (e.g., driver's license, marriage license).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the organizational structure of the federal government in the United States (legislative, executive, and judicial branches).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the powers of the federal government are separated among the branches.

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of how the system of checks and balances limits the power of the federal government (e.g., presidential veto of legislation, courts declaring a law unconstitutional, congressional approval of judicial appointments).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how the President, members of the Congress, and justices of the Supreme Court come to power (e.g., elections versus appointments).

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how the federal government uses taxing and spending to serve the purposes of government.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain responsibilities of citizenship (e.g., initiating changes in laws or policy, holding public office, respecting the law, being informed and attentive to public issues, paying taxes, registering to vote and voting knowledgeably, serving as a juror).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the relationship between rights and responsibilities of citizenship.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why rights have limits.

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe ways citizens can work together to promote the values and principles of American democracy.

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify questions economists ask in examining the United States (e.g., What is produced? How is it produced? How much is produced? Who gets what is produced? What role does the government play in the economy?).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe some characteristics of a market economy (e.g., private property rights, voluntary exchange, competition, consumer sovereignty, incentives, specialization).

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how positive and negative incentives influence behavior in a market economy.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how price affects decisions about purchasing goods and services (substitute goods).

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how specialization and division of labor increase productivity (e.g., assembly line). (H)

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how competition among buyers results in higher prices and competition among sellers results in lower prices (e.g., supply, demand).

subject: Social Studies
description: Demonstrate the circular flow model by engaging in a market simulation, which includes households and businesses and depicts the interactions among them.

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain why public goods (e.g., libraries, roads, parks, the Mackinac Bridge) are not privately owned. (H)

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain how changes in the United States economy impact levels of employment and unemployment (e.g., changing demand for natural resources, changes in technology, changes in competition). (H)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how global competition affects the national economy (e.g., outsourcing of jobs, increased supply of goods, opening new markets, quality controls).

subject: Social Studies
description: Identify public issues in the United States that influence the daily lives of its citizens.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use graphic data and other sources to analyze information about a public issue in the United States and evaluate alternative resolutions.

subject: Social Studies
description: Give examples of how conflicts over core democratic values lead people to differ on resolutions to a public policy issue in the United States.

subject: Social Studies
description: Compose a brief essay expressing a position on a public policy issue in the United States and justify the position with a reasoned argument.

subject: Social Studies
description: Develop and implement an action plan and know how, when, and where to address or inform others about a public issue.

subject: Social Studies
description: Participate in projects to help or inform others.

subject: Social Studies
description: Use maps to locate peoples in the desert Southwest, the Pacific Northwest, the nomadic nations of the Great Plains, and the woodland peoples east of the Mississippi River (Eastern Woodland). (National Geography Standard 1, p. 144)

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare how American Indians in the desert Southwest and the Pacific Northwest adapted to or modified the environment. (National Geography Standard 14, p. 171)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe Eastern Woodland American Indian life with respect to governmental and family structures, trade, and views on property ownership and land use. (National Geography Standard 11, p. 164, C, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the technological (e.g., invention of the astrolabe and improved maps), and political developments, (e.g., rise of nation-states), that made sea exploration possible. (National Geography Standard 1, p. 144, C)

subject: Social Studies
description: Use case studies of individual explorers and stories of life in Europe to compare the goals, obstacles, motivations, and consequences for European exploration and colonization of the Americas (e.g., economic, political, cultural, and religious). (National Geography Standard 13, p. 169, C, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Use maps to locate the major regions of Africa (northern Africa, western Africa, central Africa, eastern Africa, southern Africa). (National Geography Standard 1, p. 144)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the life and cultural development of people living in western Africa before the 16th century with respect to economic (the ways people made a living) and family structures, and the growth of states, towns, and trade. (National Geography Standard 10, p. 162)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the convergence of Europeans, American Indians and Africans in North America after 1492 from the perspective of these three groups. (National Geography Standard 10, p. 162)

subject: Social Studies
description: Use primary and secondary sources (e.g., letters, diaries, maps, documents, narratives, pictures, graphic data) to compare Europeans and American Indians who converged in the western hemisphere after 1492 with respect to governmental structure, and views on property ownership and land use. (National Geography Standard 12, p. 167, C, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Explain the impact of European contact on American Indian cultures by comparing the different approaches used by the British and French in their interactions with American Indians. (National Geography Standard 10, p. 162, C, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the Columbian Exchange and its impact on Europeans, American Indians, and Africans. (National Geography Standard 11, p. 164, E)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe significant developments in the Southern colonies, including

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe significant developments in the New England colonies, including

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe significant developments in the Middle Colonies, including

subject: Social Studies
description: Compare the regional settlement patterns of the Southern colonies, New England, and the Middle Colonies. (National Geography Standard 12, p. 167)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe Triangular Trade including

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe the life of enslaved Africans and free Africans in the American colonies. (National Geography Standard 5, p. 152)

subject: Social Studies
description: Describe how Africans living in North America drew upon their African past (e.g., sense of family, role of oral tradition) and adapted elements of new cultures to develop a distinct African-American culture. (National Geography Standard 10, p. 162)

subject: Social Studies
description: Locate the New England, Middle, and Southern colonies on a map. (National Geography Standard 3 p. 148)

subject: Social Studies
